entry.para: Optimal Belt Life Speed RangesStaying within the optimal belt life speed ranges will increase the rotor variable belt life because the variable sheaves operate closer to a 1:1 ratio.

note.para: For recommended machine settings for various crops, see the Crop Setting section for further information.

entry.para: Best = Provides best level of performance.
Good = Provides a good level of performance.
Average = Provides an average level of performance.

block.head: Concave Types
block.para:
Round Bar Multiple Crop Concave
Large Wire Concave
Small Wire Concave Three different concaves are available for different crop and crop conditions.

item.para: Round bar multiple crop concave is used for corn and soybeans.
Large wire concave is used for soybeans and grain sorghum.
Small wire concave is used for small grains.

block.head: Separator Grate Spacers

important.para:
Separator Grate Spacers
ASpacer BSeparator Grate CSeparator Channel
Separator grate spacers are intended for use on the first three grates on each side of the machine.
Do not install the separator grate spacers in the fourth separator gate. Installation in this separator grate may cause interference with the return auger.

block.para: Spacers are installed in the storage position (as shown) from factory.
Spacers can be used in corn to reduce bits of the cob in the grain tank sample.

important.para: Spacers should be used in corn and soybeans only. Remove spacers for all other crops (place spacers in the storage position as shown).

block.para: Remove all separator grate spacers (A) from the storage position (as shown) and install between separator grates (B) and separator channel (C).

item.para: Standard Cast Separator Grates - come standard on all machines.

block.head: Separator Grate Deflectors (If Equipped)

note.para:
Separator Grate Deflectors
ASeparator Grate Deflectors
Left-hand separator rail liners are shown. Right-hand separator rail liners are similar.

block.para: The separator grate deflectors (A) provide protection to the separator rail when harvesting abrasive crops.
Periodically inspect the left-hand and right-hand separator grate deflectors for wear.
Remove and replace separator grate deflectors as needed. See your John Deere dealer for further information.

block.object_name: Concave Sections (Active Concave Isolation)-Remove and Install
block.head: Concave Sections (Active Concave Isolation)Remove and Install

caution.para: Threshing Clearance Adjust Concave sections are heavy and awkward to handle. Another person may be needed to remove and install concave sections.

step.para: Start engine and press threshing clearance adjust switch.
To allow easier access to concaves, lower the threshing clearance to 0.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

Gear Case
AHandle BNeutral Position
Move handle (A) to shift the rotor gear case in neutral position (B).

note.para:
Separator Covers
AKnob (8 used) BLatch (9 used) CSeparator Cover (3 used)
Remove shielding as needed to access separator inspection covers.

step.para: Turn knobs (A) counterclockwise.
Turn latches (B) and remove separator inspection covers (C).

Center Brace
ACap Screw (3 used) BBrace
Remove cap screws (A) and brace (B).

Concave Removal
ACap Screw and Nut (9 used) BCap Screw and Nut (12 used) CConcave (3 used)
Remove cap screw and nut (A).
Remove cap screw and nut (B) and the concave (C).
Remove the remaining concaves.

Concave Frames
Concave Hinge
AConcave Frame (3 used) BNotch
Install the concaves onto the concave frames (A).

note.para: Verify that the notches (B) on the concaves are installed over the concave hinges as shown.

step.para:
Concave
ACap Screw and Nut (9 used) BCap Screw and Nut (12 used) CConcave (3 used)
Install cap screws and nuts (B) through the concave and concave frame.
Lift concave (C) upward and install cap screws and nuts (A).

Brace
ACap Screw (3 used) BBrace
Install brace (B) using cap screws (A).

Separator Covers
AKnob (8 used) BLatch (9 used) CSeparator Cover (3 used)
Install separator covers (C) and turn latches (B) to secure.
Turn knobs (A) clockwise to tighten.

Separator Covers
AKnob (8 used) BLatch (9 used) CSeparator Cover (3 used)
Open the front gull wing door, turn knobs (A) counterclockwise to loosen.
Turn latches (B) and remove separator covers (C).
Remove the front separator grate deflector. See Separator Grate Deflectors (If Equipped) for more information.

Separator Grate
ACap Screw (2 used) BCap Screw and Nut (3 used) CFront Separator Grate
Remove cap screws (A), cap screws and nuts (B), and the front separator grate (C).
Threshing Clearance Adjust Start engine and press threshing clearance adjust switch.
Set threshing clearance to 0. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake and remove key.

Rotor Shift Handle
AHandle BNeutral Position
Move handle (A) to shift the rotor gear case in neutral position (B).

note.para:
Concave Cylinder
ALower Lock Nut BLower Adjustment Nut CUpper Lock Nut DUpper Adjustment Nut
Verify that the concave cylinders are fully retracted.
If the concave cylinders are not fully retracted see your John Deere Dealer for more information.

step.para: Loosen the lower lock nut (A), lower adjustment nut (B), and the upper lock nut (C) on the front and rear concave cylinders.
While turning the rotor counterclockwise by hand, tighten the upper adjustment nut (D) slowly on the front concave cylinder until the elements tick against the rotor. Back off the nut one full turn.
While turning the rotor counterclockwise by hand, tighten the upper adjustment nut (D) slowly on the rear concave cylinder until the elements tick against the rotor. Back off the nut one full turn.
While turning the rotor clockwise by hand, tighten the upper adjustment nut (D) slowly on the front concave cylinder until the elements tick against the rotor. Back off the nut one full turn.
While turning the rotor clockwise by hand, tighten the upper adjustment nut (D) slowly on the rear concave cylinder until the elements tick against the rotor. Back off the nut one full turn.

Tighten the lower adjustment nut on the front and rear concave cylinders to specification.
Lower Adjustment Nut Torque 69 Nm (51 lbft)
Tighten the upper and lower lock nuts.
Install previously removed separator grate and separator grate deflector.
Install previously removed separator covers.
Repeat on the opposite side of the machine.
Shift the rotor gear case back to the original gear setting.
Perform threshing clearance calibration. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.
Set the concave back to the desired position and resume harvesting.

block.object_name: Threshing Elements and Tines-Remove and Install
block.head: Threshing Elements and TinesRemove and Install

important.para:
Threshing Element
Separator Tine
ACap Screw BCap Screw
Rotor is a balanced assembly. Elements and tines must be replaced in sets of three to maintain balance. Replacement kits are available through service parts and include new cap screws with pre-applied thread lock and sealer. Tines or elements that become loose may result in machine damage.

If tines or elements need to be removed for reasons other than replacement, mark location on tines/elements and rotor prior to removal. Install in same location as removed to maintain balance. Always use new cap screws.

Make sure to clean out tailings and front cross auger if tine replacement is due to broken or damaged tines. Failure to do so before initial start-up may allow broken tines to recirculate and cause tine damage to reoccur.

step.para: Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Remove separator grates or concave sections as needed to access rotor.
Inspect wear on threshing elements and separator tines.
Remove cap screws (AB) and threshing element or tine.
If one element or tine needs replaced, replace all in the group. Example: If element 2 needs to be replaced, replace elements 1 and 3 also.
Use Threshing Elements and Separator Tine Location diagram for identifying elements and tines.
Install threshing element or tine using previously removed cap screws.
Threshing Element: Tighten cap screw (A) to specification. Tighten cap screw (B) to specification. Verify correct torque on cap screw (A).

Separator Tine: Tighten both cap screws to specification.
Threshing Element and Separator Tine Cap Screws
Torque 82 Nm (60 lbft)

block.head: Threshing Element and Separator Tine Location

Remove cleaning fan belt and install replacement belt.

Install previously removed cleaning fan fixed drive belt.
Install previously removed front left-hand shields.

Cleaning Fan Drive Belt
ACap Screw (4 used) BCap Screw CBracket
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

Remove tension from cleaning fan variable drive belt. See Cleaning Fan Variable Drive Sheave GapAdjusting.
Remove cap screws (A and B) and bracket (C).
Remove cleaning fan variable drive belt and install replacement belt.

important.para: Tighten cap screw (B) before tightening cap screws (A).

step.para:
Reinstall bracket and cap screws and tighten to specification.

Cap Screw (A) Torque 128 Nm (94 lbft)

important.para:
Closed/Open

Cleaning Fan Variable Speed Drive Sheave Gap
Driver Pulley Removed for Clarity
ACap Screw (4 used) BNut CTurnbuckle DSheave Gap

Front Step Pan
Deflectors Diverting Away from Bays 3 and 4
Deflectors Diverting Away from Bays 1 and 6
ACap Screw and Nut (8 used) BDeflector (2 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove the separator covers to access the front step pan.
Remove cap screws and nuts (A) from both deflectors (B).

important.para: Orient the deflectors in either position shown. Installing the deflectors in any other position will result in machine damage.

step.para: Remove deflectors and reorient them to a position that pulls material from the bays with the highest volume of crop to the bays with the lowest volume.

Install the deflectors and retain with cap screws and nuts. Tighten to specification.
Cap Screws and Nuts Torque 10 Nm (96 lbin)

caution.para:
Front Chaffer
AAdjustment Linkage
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove left-hand separator covers to access the front chaffer.
Turn adjustment linkage (A) clockwise to close the chaffer and counterclockwise to open the chaffer.
Close chaffer louvers past the desired set point and then open louvers to the desired set point to remove play.
Adjust front chaffer to desired position with adjustment linkage.

important.para:
Chaffer/Sieve Switch
AChaffer Adjust Switch BSieve Adjust Switch
Close chaffer/sieve louvers completely to prevent louver damage while removing chaffer/sieve.

step.para: The chaffer adjust switch (A) and sieve adjust switch (B) are located on the left-hand side of the machine.
The chaffer adjust switch and sieve adjust switch allow the operator to open or close the chaffer and sieve to various positions.

subblock.head: Louver Length
subblock.para:
Chaffer/Sieve Louver Length
AWire-to-Wire
Machines can be equipped with two different types of chaffer and sieves.

item.para: Deep-tooth chaffer and sieve
Chaffer 41 mm (1-5/8 in)
Sieve 30 mm (1-3/16 in)
General-purpose chaffer and sieve
Chaffer 30 mm (1-3/16 in)
Sieve 30 mm (1-3/16 in)
Flat-tooth comb chaffer and sieve
Chaffer 30 mm (1-3/16 in)
Sieve 30 mm (1-3/16 in)

subblock.para: Proper way to measure chaffer and sieve louver length is from wire-to-wire (A) as shown. This can be used to determine if a deep-tooth, general-purpose, or flat-tooth comb chaffer or sieve is installed.

subblock.head: Sieve Louver Depth
subblock.para:
Sieve Louver Depth
ALouver Depth
Machines can be equipped with two different types of sieves.

item.para: Deep-tooth sieve
Sieve 22 mm (7/8 in)
General-purpose sieve
Sieve 10 mm (3/8 in)

subblock.para: Proper way to measure sieve louver depth (A) is from bottom of louver to tip of louver as shown. This can be used to determine if a deep-tooth or general-purpose sieve is installed.

subblock.head: Louver Clearance

note.para:
Chaffer/Sieve Louver Clearance
ALouver-to-Louver
Always close the chaffer/sieve louvers past the desired set point and then open the louvers to the desired set point to remove play.

subblock.para: Proper way to measure chaffer and sieve clearance is from louver-to-louver (A) as shown. This can be used to determine if clearance on chaffer and sieve matches with setting shown on armrest display.

block.head: General-Purpose Chaffer 30 mm (1-3/16 in)

note.para: General-Purpose Chaffer Dimension shown is wire-to-wire spacing.

block.para: General-purpose chaffer is suitable for corn, soybeans, sorghum, small grains, oil seed crops, grass seed, and many specialty crops. It is recommended for dry conditions and is resistant to stabbing of corn tassels and soybean, sunflower, and sorghum stems.

block.head: Deep-Tooth Chaffer 41 mm (1-5/8 in)

note.para: Deep-Tooth Chaffer Dimension shown is wire-to-wire spacing.
Not recommended for use in small grains, food corn, or popcorn.

block.para: Deep-tooth chaffer and deep-tooth sieve provide additional grain separation capacity in high moisture and high yield corn and high-capacity and clean grain sample in corn and soybeans.

block.head: Flat-Tooth Comb Chaffer 30 mm (1-3/16 in)

note.para: Flat-Tooth Comb Chaffer Dimension shown is wire-to-wire spacing.
The flat-tooth comb chaffer requires a 23 mm wider chaffer clearance opening and 50 rpm higher fan speed compared to the general-purpose chaffer.

block.para: The flat-tooth comb chaffer improves tailings volume and grain tank sample, especially in challenging conditions (weedy conditions and heavily bearded crops), such as canola, oil seed (rape), and lentils. The curled chaffer finger reduces the amount of longer sticks passing through the chaffer.

block.head: General Purpose Sieve 30 mm (1-3/16 in)

note.para: Sieve Dimension shown is wire-to-wire spacing.

block.para: This sieve is suitable for all major crops and many specialty crops.

block.head: Deep-Tooth Sieve 30 mm (1-3/16 in)

note.para: Deep Tooth Sieve Dimension shown is wire-to-wire spacing.
Not recommended for use in small grains, food corn, or popcorn.

block.para: Deep-tooth sieve provides additional grain separation in high-moisture and high-yield corn.
This sieve together with the deep-tooth chaffer provides high-capacity and clean grain samples in corn and soybeans.

step.para:
Chopper Adjusting Switch
AChopper Adjusting Switch
Raise the chopper using the chopper adjusting switch (A).

caution.para:
Tailboard
ACap Screw (12 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: To avoid damage to chaffer/sieve elements, completely close the louvers before removing the elements from the machine.

note.para: It is not necessary to remove the chopper to remove the chaffer/sieve elements. The chopper must be fully raised.
The sieve removal is similar to the chaffer removal.

step.para: Remove cap screws (A) on both sides of the machine and remove the tailboard.

Chaffer Element
AElectrical Connector (2 used) BCap Screw (6 used) CBushing (2 used)
Remove electrical connector (A) from both sides of the chaffer element.

note.para: Bushing (C) can be used to assist in removing and installing the chaffer element.

step.para: Remove cap screws (B) and slide the chaffer element out of the rear of the machine.
Inspect the grain seals on the chaffer element and repair or replace as needed.

Chaffer Element Rail
AUpper Hole BCap Screw CLower Hole
Remove the cap screw from hole (A), loosen cap screw (B), and tilt the chaffer element rail up until hole (C) aligns with the hole in the side sheet and reinstall the cap screw. Repeat of the opposite side of the machine.

Sieve Element
AElectrical Connector (2 used) BCap Screws (6 used)
Remove electrical connector (A) from both sides of the sieve element.
Remove cap screws (B), tilt the sieve element and slide it out of the rear of the machine.
Inspect the grain seals on the sieve element and repair or replace as needed.

Sieve Element
AElectrical Connector (2 used) BCap Screws (6 used)
Install the sieve element through the rear of the machine.
Connect electrical connector (A) to both sides of the machine and install cap screws (B).

Tighten cap screws to specification.
Sieve Cap Screws Torque 37 Nm (27 lbft)

Chaffer Element Rail
AUpper Hole BCap Screw CLower Hole
Remove cap screw from hole (C), tilt the chaffer element down until the hole (A) aligns with the hole in the side sheet and reinstall the cap screw.
Tighten cap screw (B) and repeat steps (C and D) on the opposite side of the machine.

Chaffer Element
AElectrical Connector (2 used) BCap Screw (6 used)
Install the chaffer element through the rear of the machine.
Connect electrical connector (A) to both sides of the machine and install cap screws (B).

Tighten cap screws to specification.
Chaffer Cap Screws Torque 37Nm (27 lbft)

Tailboard
ACap Screws (2 used) BCap Screw (12 used)
To help support the tailboard during the installation, install cap screw (A) into the side sheet on both sides of the machine.
Hook the tailboard onto the previously installed cap screws on both sides of the machine.
Align holes on the tailboard with the side sheet holes and install cap screws (B) on both sides of the machine.

Tighten cap screws to specification.
Sidesheet Cap Screws Torque 26 Nm (20 lbft)

block.head: Chaffer/Sieve/Return Pan Assemblies
block.para: The following assemblies contain non-serviceable structural fasteners and are not repairable:

item.para: Left and Right Chaffer Frame Sides
Left and Right Sieve Frame Sides
Return Pan Frame
Front Step Pan Frame
Chaffer Element
Sieve Element

note.para: The listed assemblies can be replaced through service parts. See your John Deere dealer for more information.

step.para:
Adjusting Motor
AKnob
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: To prevent motor damage, do not use a wrench on knob.

step.para: Use knob (A) to adjust motor. Turn the knob clockwise to close and counterclockwise to open the chaffer/sieve.
Close the chaffer/sieve louvers past the desired set point and then open the louvers to the desired set point to remove play.

caution.para:
Clean Grain Elevator Belt
ALock Nut BNut CWasher DGauge
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Loosen lock nut (A).
Tighten nut (B) until the washer (C) is positioned between the end of the gauge (D) and the bottom of the step.

Tighten lock nut to specification.
Lock Nut Torque 24 Nm (212 lbin)

caution.para:
Clean Grain Elevator Belt
ANut (2 used) BClean Grain Elevator Belt
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Loosen nuts (A) to remove tension from the clean grain elevator belt (B).
Remove clean grain elevator belt and install replacement belt.
Adjust clean grain elevator belt. See Clean Grain Elevator BeltAdjusting.

block.object_name: Clean Grain Elevator Wear Plates and Door (If Equipped)
block.head: Clean Grain Elevator Wear Plates and Door (If Equipped)
block.para: Clean Grain Elevator Wear Plates and Door The following parts provide protection to the clean grain elevator when harvesting abrasive crops:

item.para: Rear Wear Plate (A)
Wear Plate (B)
Door (C)

block.para: Periodically inspect these clean grain elevator parts for wear.
Remove and replace these clean grain elevator parts as needed. See your John Deere dealer for further information.

note.para:
Separator Sensors
Shoe Sensors
ASensor
Two people are required to perform this operational check. One person must remain seated in the operator's seat, while another person taps on the sensors.
Separator sensors are on the left-hand side of the machine underneath the separator covers.
Shoe sensors are at the rear of the machine on the tailboard.

step.para: Turn key switch to RUN position, but do not start machine.
Engage header switch.

note.para: The VisionTrak system MUST be in a crop that was previously calibrated. Grain loss calibration value MUST be less than 50.

step.para: Tap on sensors (A) several times. Person watching VisionTrakVisionTrak is a trademark of Deere & Company display should see movement on the shoe loss and separator loss indicators.

note.para: Return grain loss calibration value to original value or perform another crop calibration.

step.para: Disengage header switch and turn key switch OFF.
If VisionTrak does not work after these checks, see your John Deere dealer for further information.

block.head: Tailings System Elevator Sensors
block.para:
Tailings Sensor
ATailings Sensor
If tailings sensor display consistently reads full (all bars lit) when not harvesting or empty (no bars lit) when harvesting, it may indicate that the sensor lens is coated with material or seal under lens has allowed dust to enter.

caution.para: Tailings sensor is a Class 1 laser product and emits laser radiation when powered. When servicing or removing tailings sensors, use caution and do not view beam directly.
Key switch must be turned OFF and tailings sensor must be unplugged before servicing or removing sensors.

block.para: DO NOT operate sensor with lens removed. Accessible laser emission when the lens is in place:

item.para: 850 nm
500 nsec pulse width
500 Hz rep rate
< 90 nJ per pulse
43 uW average power
Class 1 levels (eye safe)

block.para: Accessible laser emission levels if sensor was operated with lens removed are:

item.para: 850 nm
500 nsec pulse width
500 Hz rep rate
< 380 nJ per pulse
188 uW average power
Class 3R levels (small potential for eye injury)
Remove tailings sensors (A) to inspect and clean the lenses if needed.
If the lenses are clean, remove and check for dust. If dust is found, clean the area and reassemble the lens onto the unit, making sure that the gasket is sealing.
Verify that the lens is retained with all previously removed screws prior to installation.

caution.para: Failure to install the plastic cover prior to replacement of the sensors on the elevator may cause malfunction, incorrect harvest readings, or sensor damage and could allow for potentially hazardous eye exposure when the sensor is removed.

item.para: Install the sensor and test the system.
If the display continues to read full or empty, contact your John Deere dealer.

block.object_name: Tailings System and Clean Grain Elevator Paddles
block.head: Tailings System and Clean Grain Elevator Paddles

caution.para: Elevator Paddles Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

block.para: Check the elevator chain occasionally for worn or missing paddles.
In muddy conditions, one steel paddle may be installed in the elevator chain to act as a wiper.

block.object_name: Tailings System and Clean Grain Elevator Paddle Chain-Adjusting
block.head: Tailings System and Clean Grain Elevator Paddle ChainAdjusting

caution.para:
Tailings System Elevator
ANut (4 used) BNut (2 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Release the latch and open the lower door.
Remove the nuts from the bearing cover.
Loosen nuts (A) and use nuts (B) to adjust the chain. Move the bearing carrier downward to tighten the chain.

The elevator chain is adjusted properly when the lower end of the chain can be moved side-to-side on the sprocket but cannot be pulled away from the sprocket. When the chain loosens up to 6 mm (1/4 in) from the sprocket, readjust the chain. After a period of use, it may be necessary to remove a half link to adjust the chain correctly.
Install the bearing cover and retain with nuts.
Close and latch the lower door.

block.object_name: Tailings System Wear Strips and Rasp Bars-Remove and Install
block.head: Tailings System Wear Strips and Rasp BarsRemove and Install

caution.para:
Tailings System Belt Tensioner
ANut (2 used) BTailings and Cleaning Fan Drive Belt
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Loosen nuts (A) to relieve belt tension from the tailings and cleaning fan drive belt (B).

Tailings System Cover
ACap Screw (3 used) BStrap CShoulder Bolt (2 used) DCap Screw ERod FAccess Cover
Remove cap screws (A) and strap (B).
Remove shoulder bolts (C), cap screw (D), and rod (E) from access cover (F).

Wear Strips
ACap Screw and Nut BWear Strip
Remove cap screws and nuts (A) from wear strips (B).
Remove and replace wear strips as needed.

Tighten wear strip cap screws to specification.
Wear Strip Cap Screws Torque 70 Nm (52 lbft)

Rasp Bars
ACap Screw and Nut BRasp Bar
Remove cap screws and nuts (A) from rasp bar (B).
Remove and replace rasp bars as needed.

Tighten rasp bar cap screws to specification.
Rasp Bar Cap Screws Torque 37 Nm (27 lbft)

note.para: Verify that seals on access cover remain in place when installing onto the tailings system.

step.para: Install access cover and retain with rod and cap screw.
Install shoulder bolts, align rubber piece with holes, and install strap and cap screws.
Adjust tailings system drive belt tensioner until washer is positioned between end of gauge and bottom of step.

block.object_name: Tailings System Wear Strips and Rasp Bars-Adjusting
block.head: Tailings System Wear Strips and Rasp BarsAdjusting

caution.para:
Tailings and Cleaning Fan Drive Belt
ANut (2 used) BTailings and Cleaning Fan Drive Belt
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove the tailings elevator shield. See Left-Hand Side Shields.
Loosen nuts (A) to remove tension form the tailings and cleaning fan drive belt (B).
Remove tailings and cleaning fan drive belt to allow tailings system to turn freely.

note.para:
Adjusting Wear Strips and Rasp Bars
AAdjustment Handle BCap Screw, M6 CCap Screw and Nut
Moving adjustment handle downward zeroes the position between wear strips and rasp bars.

step.para: Move adjustment handle (A) downward as shown and install cap screws (B) in existing holes.
Loosen cap screws and nuts (C).
Slowly adjust access door while rotating beater until ticking is heard.
Slowly back off until ticking stops and tighten cap screws and nuts.
Install previously removed belt and adjust the tensioner until washer is positioned between end of gauge and bottom of step.
Install previously removed shield.

block.head: Tailings System Return ConcaveAdjusting

caution.para:
Crop Selection Handle
ACrop Selection Handle BSmall Grain Position CLarge Grain Position
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: To prevent personal injury or machine damage, do not move crop selection handle when machine is running.

note.para: See Crop Settings section for recommended tailings system concave position settings.

block.para: Crop selection handle (A) should be in LOWER position when harvesting small grain crops.
Crop selection handle (A) should be in UPPER position when harvesting large crops or damage-sensitive crops.

caution.para:
Tailings System Auger Cleanout Door
AHandle
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Use handle (A) to open tailings system auger cleanout door.
Remove material as needed.

legend.def: Cleaning Fan Rear/Tailings Inner Drive Belt
Feed Accelerator Gear Case Drive Belt

caution.para: Make sure that bystanders are clear of machine when starting engine and when engaging separator.

note.para: Use the feed accelerator unplugging tool (if available). See your John Deere dealer for further information.

step.para: Disengage the separator.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Shift the separator drive gear case to the neutral position.
Shift the feed accelerator gear case to the neutral position.
Open the stone trap door and clean. Leave the stone trap door open.
Sound horn, start engine, and set engine speed at mid idle.
Engage the separator to clean material out of the discharge beater, and chopper.
Engage the feeder house reverser to clean material out of the feeder house.
Disengage the feeder house reverser and separator.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Remove the feed accelerator access covers and remove the crop material from the accelerator area. After clearing plug, rotate feeder accelerator one revolution to be sure that it is free.
Shift the feed accelerator drive by setting the gear case to low-speed.
Sound horn, start engine, and set engine speed at low idle.
Engage the separator. If the plug does not clear, disengage the separator and repeat steps 1014.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Close the stone trap door and set the concave spacing back to original setting. Replace the feed accelerator access covers.
Shift the separator drive gear case back to the original gear setting and resume operation.

caution.para: Make sure that bystanders are clear of machine when starting engine and when engaging separator.

step.para: Disengage the separator.

note.para: Remember the concave setting and adjust the concave to wide-open position.

step.para: Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Shift the separator drive gear case to the neutral position.
Shift the feed accelerator gear case to the neutral position.
Open the stone trap door and clean. Close the stone trap door.
Sound horn, start engine, and set the engine speed at mid idle.
Engage the separator to clean out material from the discharge beater.
Disengage the separator.
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Shift the separator drive gear case to first gear.
Sound horn, start engine, and set the engine speed at mid idle.

important.para: To prevent damage to the main engine gear case and wet clutch, do not engage the separator clutch with a plugged separator more than three times in a period of 3 minutes.
Wait for 1 minute between plugged separator engagements while idling the machine.

step.para: Engage the separator to clear the separator. If the plug does not clear, disengage the separator.
If the separator cannot be power unplugged, it is necessary to remove the concaves as needed to remove the straw by hand. After clearing plug, replace the concaves.
After the separator is unplugged, set the concave spacing back to the original setting.
Shift the feed accelerator drive by setting the gear case back to the original gear setting.
Shift the separator drive gear case back to the original gear setting and resume operation.

caution.para: Make sure that bystanders are clear of machine when starting engine and when engaging separator.

step.para: Disengage the header and separator.

note.para: Remember the concave setting and adjust the concave to wide-open position.

step.para: Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Raise the straw chopper and remove the material from the chopper area.
Lower the straw chopper to the operating position.
Shift the feed accelerator gear case to the neutral position.
Shift the separator drive gear case to the neutral position.
Sound horn, start engine, and set engine speed at mid idle.
Engage the separator to clean out material from the discharge beater and chopper.
Disengage the separator.
If the separator is not unplugged:
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
To access the discharge beater area, remove the covers and remove the crop material from the discharge beater area.
Repeat steps 59.
After the separator is unplugged, set the concave spacing back to the original setting.
Shift the feed accelerator drive by setting the gear case back to the original gear setting.
Shift the separator drive gear case back to the original gear setting and resume operation.
If the separator is unplugged:
Set the concave spacing back to the original setting.
Shift the feed accelerator drive by setting the gear case back to the original gear setting.
Shift the separator drive gear case back to the original gear setting and resume operation.

block.head: Residue Material Handling Option (Standard Residue)

note.para:
Chopping Standard
Windrow Standard Solid arrows represent flow of straw. Dashed arrows represent flow of chaff.

block.para: Straw and chaff get laid down together in a windrow.

block.head: Residue Material Handling Option (Premium Residue)

note.para:
Chopping Premium
Windrow Premium Solid arrows represent flow of straw. Dashed arrows represent flow of chaff.

block.para: Capability to drop straw and spread chaff.

note.para: Windrowing Standard Solid arrows represent flow of straw. Dashed arrows represent flow of chaff.

item.para: Raise chopper fully. See Chopper Adjusting switch later in this section.
Shift chopper drive into neutral position. See Chopper Drive SpeedsChanging later in this section.

note.para: Windrowing Premium Solid arrows represent flow of straw. Dashed arrows represent flow of chaff.

item.para: To windrow straw and spread chaff, open chop-to-drop door (premium model). See Residue Management Application Help or Operator's Station Help for further information.

block.head: Windrow Convergence Rakes Option (Standard Residue)
block.para:
Windrow Rakes
AConvergence Rakes
Convergence rakes (A) are used to divert straw material into a narrower windrow. See your John Deere dealer for further information on the convergence rakes.

block.head: Windrow Side CurtainAdjusting (Premium Residue)
block.para:
Windrow Side Curtain
ALatch (2 used)
Turn latches (A) to adjust the windrow side curtains to divert straw material into narrower windrows.
Move the windrow side curtains inward when the windrow is too flat.
Move the windrow side curtains outward when the windrow is too tall.

caution.para:
Total Loss Curtain
AQuick-Lock Pin (12 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove quick-lock pins (A) and the curtain.

Total Loss Curtain
AShift Lever
Shift the chopper into neutral position using the shift lever (A).
Raise the chopper fully with the switch located on the left-hand side of the machine.

Viewed from inside Chopper
AQuick-Lock Pin (6 used)
Unfold the previously removed curtain.
Attach the upper portion of the curtain to the chop-to-drop door using the previously removed quick-lock pins (A).

Total Loss Curtain
AQuick-Lock Pin (6 used)
Attach the lower portion of the curtain to the chopper housing using the previously removed quick-lock pins (A).
Activate the total loss mode. See Residue Management Application Help or Operator's Station Help for further information.

note.para: Reverse steps, as needed, to return the curtain to the storage position.

caution.para:
Spreader Hardware
Paddle Assembly
ACap Screw and Nut (22 used) BCotter Pin CCastle Nut
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Disk assemblies weigh approximately 32 kg (71 lb).

important.para: Disk assemblies are specific for left-hand and right-hand sides. Mark paddle assembly locations before removing.

step.para: Remove cap screws and nuts (A).
Remove cotter pin (B) and castle nut (C).

important.para: Paddle Assembly When replacing worn or damaged paddles, make sure to replace the paddles on the opposite sides of the disk at the same time to maintain disk rotational balance.

step.para:
Install the replacement paddles as needed and tighten the hardware to specification.
Paddle Hardware Torque 65 Nm (48 lbft)

Paddle Assembly
Spreader Hardware
ACap Screw and Nut (22 used) BCotter Pin CCastle Nut
Install the disk assemblies at the same locations as previously removed.

Install the previously removed castle nut (C) and tighten to specification.
Castle Nut Torque 150 Nm (111 lbft)
Install the previously removed cotter pin (B).
Install the previously removed floor and retain with the previously removed cap screws and nuts (A).

block.head: Air Chutes
block.para:
Air Chute
AAir Chute
Air chute (A) on both sides of the separator side sheet allows the cleaning shoe to breathe more freely, especially when running on low speed. Depending on harvesting conditions, the grain tank quality may be enhanced and feeder house dust reduced.

block.head: Chopper Controller Bar

caution.para:
Controller Bar
AHardware BController Bar (2 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: The controller bars must be removed and placed in the storage position when harvesting corn.

block.para: The controller bars improve cut quality, distribution, and spread width in tough straw conditions. See your John Deere dealer for further information.

block.head: Chopper Stationary Knife Bank (Manual Knife)Adjusting

caution.para:
Knife Bank
ALatch BHandle
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: The knife bank must be fully disengaged for corn.

note.para: The chopper can be run with the knives disengaged. However, cut quality decreases.
Use the position in between the engaged and disengaged positions to optimize the power consumption and achieve satisfactory cut length.

block.para: The knives can be adjusted to any position. Position of the knives determines cut length of the material.

step.para: Open latch (A) on the chopper.
Move adjustment handle (B) downward until the knife bank is at the top of the adjustment slot.
Close the latch to lock the knife bank into position.
Open latch (A) on the chopper.
Move adjustment handle (B) upward until the knife bank is at the bottom of the adjustment slot.
Close the latch to lock the knife bank into position.

block.object_name: Chopper Stationary Knife Bank Electric Actuator-Removing

Upper Actuator Bracket
ACap Screw BNut (2 used) CUpper Actuator Bracket

Electric Actuator
AElectrical Connector BSpring Pin CPin DSpring Pin EActuator FPin GWasher

Remove spring pin (B) and pin (C).
Remove spring pin (D).
While supporting actuator (E), remove the pin (F) and washer (G).
Remove actuator from chopper.

Knife Bank Hardware (Storage Position)
ANut (2 used) BSpacer (2 used) CRound-Head Cap Screw (2 used)
Remove nut (A), spacer (B), and round-head cap screw (C) from both sides of the machine.

Hole (C) - Knife bank 50% engaged.
Hole (D) - Knife bank 0% engaged.

Install previously removed spacer (A) between the knife bank (B) and the side sheet (C) on both sides of the machine.
Install previously removed round-head cap screw (D) and nut (E) on both sides of the machine.

Knife Bank Hardware

ACap Screw BNut (2 used) CUpper Actuator Bracket

Actuator Mounting
AElectrical Connector BSpring Pin CPin DSpring Pin EActuator FPin GWasher
Actuator must be fully retracted before installing.

step.para: Install actuator (E) as shown.
Install washer (G), pin (F), and spring pin (D).
Install pin (C) and spring pin (B).
Connect electrical connector (A).

Upper Actuator Bracket
ACap Screw BNut (2 used) CUpper Actuator Bracket
Lift the upper actuator bracket (C) until the knife bank is in the fully out position and the slide linkage is under tension. Tighten cap screw (A) and nuts (B).

note.para: Position reading does not reflect the actual position of the knife bank when the separator is shutoff.

caution.para:
Manual Knife Bank
ALatch BHandle
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key. Knife blades are sharp.

step.para: Open latch (A) on the chopper.
Move adjustment handle (B) upward until the knife bank is at the bottom of the adjustment slot.

Knife Bank Tension Rod
ALatch BTension Rod
Twist latch (A) to remove.

note.para: Retain the bushings at the outer ends of the knife bank for later assembly.

Chopper Knives
ALock Nut (6 used) BCap Screw (5 used) CRetaining Rod

Install the previously removed lock nuts and cap screws.

note.para: Reposition the bushings at the outer ends of the knife bank.

Install the latch.
Adjust the knife bank to the desired position.

important.para: The knife bank must be fully disengaged for corn.

step.para: Twist the latch and close to lock the knife bank into position.

Knife Bank Adjust Hardware
ANut
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key. Knife blades are sharp.

step.para: Remove nut (A) from the left-hand side of the knife bank adjust.

Tension Rod Assembly
AKnife Bank BTension Rod
Retain the bushings at the outer ends of the knife bank for later assembly.

step.para: While supporting knife bank (A), remove tension rod (B) from the right-hand side of the machine.

Chopper Knives
ALock Nut (6 used) BCap Screw (5 used) CRetaining Rod
Remove lock nuts (A) and cap screws (B).
Slide the retaining rod (C) until it clears the knives that need replaced.
Reverse the knives for more usage or replace the knives if they are worn on both sides.

Chopper Access Door
ALock Nut (4 used) BLock Nut (6 used) CCap Screw (5 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove lock nuts (A) from both sides of the chopper.
Remove lock nuts (B) from both sides of the chopper.
Remove cap screws (C) and the chopper access door.
Install the access door before operating the machine.

subblock.head: Blade Configuration

important.para:
Fine Cut Chopper
Extra-Fine Cut Chopper
ADChopper Blade
The chopper balance MUST be maintained. Replace BOTH blades on a single support and BOTH blades on the opposite support (180 degrees). Four blades MUST be installed to replace one broken blade, or all the blades can be replaced at one time. This MUST be done to maintain balance.

subblock.para: If any blade (AD) is broken, replace blades (AD).

note.para:
Fine Cut Chopper Blades
ALock Nut BCap Screw CBushing (2 used) DBushing (2 used)
If removing the blades or bushings for inspection purposes, be certain to reinstall the blades on the SAME support from which they were removed. This must be done to maintain balance. It is a good practice to mark each blade before removal.
When installing or replacing the blades, install new cap screws and lock nuts in the same direction as the hardware that was previously removed.

step.para: Remove lock nut (A) and cap screw (B).
Remove and inspect bushings (C and D).

caution.para:
Grain Tank Sensors (Grain Tank Covers)
A3/4 Full Sensor B4/4 Full Sensor CHoles
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

note.para: Header drive must be engaged for the buzzer to sound.

step.para: The grain tank 3/4 full sensor (A) is on the right-hand grain tank extension or the grain tank cover.
Adjust the sensor by moving it higher or lower in the slot or holes (C) to adjust the switch "trip" point. The higher the sensor is positioned, the fuller the grain tank is when the buzzer sounds.
The grain tank 3/4 full icon appears on the display when the grain reaches the sensor.
When the grain tank is 3/4 full, the beacon lights illuminate to provide a signal to the grain cart operator that the grain tank is nearly full.
The grain tank 4/4 full sensor (B) is on the right-hand grain tank extension or the grain tank cover.
Adjust the sensor by moving it higher or lower in the slot or holes to adjust the switch "trip" point. The higher the sensor is positioned, the fuller the grain tank is when the buzzer sounds.
The grain tank 4/4 full icon appears on the display when the grain reaches the sensor.

block.head: Grain Tank CoversOperating

caution.para: Folding Button The grain tank covers must be closed and the radio antenna removed and placed in the manual storage location compartment located behind the operators seat before transporting the machine on the roadway. Avoid contact with low-hanging power lines and tree limbs.

important.para: Grain tank must be empty before folding grain tank covers.

note.para: Grain tank covers must be opened all the way in order to engage separator.
Clean grain loading auger rises when grain tank covers are opened. Auger swings down when covers are closed.

block.para: Press folding button on navigation bar. See Folding Application Help or Operator's Station Help for further information on raising or lowering grain tank covers.

caution.para:
Grain Tank Covers Eyebolt
ANut BBolt CNominal Distance, 72 mm (2-13/16 in)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

note.para: Only adjust turnbuckles on the left-hand side of machine. Turnbuckles on the right-hand side of machine are not adjustable.

step.para: Raise the grain tank covers fully.

note.para: The nominal distance does not include the nuts.

step.para: Loosen nut (A) and adjust the bolt (B) until a nominal distance (C) is achieved between the turnbuckle ends as shown.

note.para: Increasing turnbuckle distance increases clearance between left cover and front/rear covers.
Decreasing turnbuckle distance decreases clearance between left cover and front/rear covers.

step.para: Tighten the nut when distance is achieved.
Repeat as needed on the remaining turnbuckle.

block.head: Grain Tank Cross Auger Covers

caution.para:
Auger Cover
ASpring Pin (2 used) BHandle (2 used) CLower Hole DUpper Hole
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: If the auger covers are adjusted too far, auger drive shear bolt can break repeatedly, or damage can occur to the augers or the grain tank.

block.para: Auger covers are used to adjust the unloading rate. To adjust auger covers:

step.para: Remove spring pin (A) and slide the handles (B) toward the inside of the cross auger cover.
Place the auger cover in the desired position and slide the handles into the appropriate lower or upper holes (C and D).
Install the previously removed spring pin.
Repeat the procedure on the opposite side of the cross auger cover.

note.para: If needed, adjust the cross auger covers up or down to increase or decrease flow rate depending on the crop type and moisture conditions. Adjusting the cross auger covers also affects the unload system power consumption.

caution.para:
ActiveYield Right-Side Harness
ActiveYield Left-Side Harness
AClamp (7 used) BGrain Tank Harness Connector (2 used) CActiveYield Sensor Harness Connector (4 used) DSpring Pin (6 used) EHandle (6 used)
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: Use extra care when removing and installing auger covers. Do not stand on, drop, or allow objects to fall onto sensors.

note.para: In certain crop conditions and speciality crops, cross auger covers must be removed.

ActiveYieldActiveYield is a trademark of Deere & Company system MUST be disabled when cross auger covers are removed. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.

step.para: Remove the wiring harnesses from clamps (A) as needed.
Disconnect grain tank connectors (B) from the front cross auger connectors (C).
Disconnect the front cross auger connector from the rear cross auger connector.
Connect the grain tank connectors together and retain with clamps as needed.

important.para: Connect harnesses together to enable yield monitoring, even if ActiveYield is disabled. To prevent contact with cross augers, retain wiring harness with clamps.

step.para: Remove spring pin (D), then twist the handle (E) upward and towards the inside of the grain tank on both sides of the machine.
Remove the auger cover from the machine and repeat on the remaining auger cover.

block.para: ActiveYieldActiveYield is a trademark of Deere & Company uses sensors (A) located in the grain tank on the cross auger covers to measure the mass of harvested grain.

important.para: Do not install a tire inner tube or a sack to end of unloading auger. Any restriction at the end of the auger can damage the unloading auger system and could cause shear bolt failure.

Loading Auger Gear Case Drive Belt

important.para: Do not jump-start engines with arc welding equipment. Currents and voltages are too high and may cause permanent damage.

step.para: Disconnect the negative (-) battery cable(s).
Disconnect the positive (+) battery cable(s).
Connect the positive and negative cables together. Do not attach to vehicle frame.
Clear or move any wiring harness sections away from welding area.
Connect welder ground close to welding point and away from control units.
After welding, reverse Steps 15.

block.object_name: Keep Electronic Control Unit Connectors Clean
block.head: Keep Electronic Control Unit Connectors Clean

important.para: Do not open control unit and do not clean with a high-pressure spray. Moisture, dirt, and other contaminants may cause permanent damage.

step.para: Keep terminals clean and free of foreign debris. Moisture, dirt, and other contaminants may cause the terminals to erode over time and not make a good electrical connection.
If a connector is not in use, put on the proper dust cap or an appropriate seal to protect it from foreign debris and moisture.
Control units are not repairable.
Since control units are the components LEAST likely to fail, isolate failure before replacing by completing a diagnostic procedure. (See your John Deere dealer.)
The wiring harness terminals and connectors for electronic control units are repairable.

caution.para: Batteries Machine must be on a flat surface to accurately check fluid levels. Battery fluid level should be visible at the top of each fill port covering the plates in each cell.

Keep all sparks and flames away from batteries as gas given off by electrolyte is explosive. To avoid sparks, connect ground cable last and disconnect it first. To avoid shocks and burns, turn battery disconnect switch OFF before servicing any part of the electrical system or when removing batteries.

block.object_name: Basic Electrical Component Handling - Precautions for Vehicles Equipped with Computer Controlled Systems
block.head: Basic Electrical Component Handling / Precautions for Vehicles Equipped with Computer Controlled Systems

item.para: Never disconnect the batteries while the key switch is on and the engine is running.
Why: This can cause electrical voltage spikes that can damage electronic components.
Do not connect jumper cables while the key switch is on.
Why: This can cause electrical voltage spikes that can damage electronic components.
Disconnect batteries prior to recharging (if possible)
Why: Electrical loads in the machine can slow the recharging process. Battery chargers can cause electrical voltage spikes that can damage electronic components.
Never jump start the machine with a voltage higher than the machine is designed to operate on
Why: This can damage electronic components
Do not connect or disconnect electrical connectors while the key switch is on or the machine is running.
Why: This can cause computer system errors from interrupting a computer program while it is running and electrical voltage spikes that are produced can damage electronic components.
Do not apply power or ground to any component as a test unless specifically instructed to do so.
Why: Connecting the wrong voltage to the wrong point of an electronic system can cause electronic component failures.
When welding on the machine, make sure to connect ground lead to the parts being welded. For maximum protection disconnect all electronic controllers before welding.

Why: The high currents associated with welding can damage wiring harnesses that are involved in the ground path. Welding can also cause electrical voltage spikes that can damage electronic components.

block.head: Handling Batteries Safely
block.para: Battery gas can explode. Keep sparks and flames away from batteries. Use a flashlight to check battery electrolyte level.
Never check battery charge by placing a metal object across the posts. Use a voltmeter or hydrometer.
Always remove grounded (-) battery clamp first and replace grounded clamp last.
Sulfuric acid in battery electrolyte is poisonous and strong enough to burn skin, eat holes in clothing, and cause blindness if splashed into eyes.

item.para: Filling batteries in a well-ventilated area
Wearing eye protection and rubber gloves
Avoiding use of air pressure to clean batteries
Avoiding breathing fumes when electrolyte is added
Avoiding spilling or dripping electrolyte
Using correct battery booster or charger procedure.

para.emph: If acid is spilled on skin or in eyes:

item.para: Flush skin with water.
Apply baking soda or lime to help neutralize the acid.
Flush eyes with water for 1530 minutes. Get medical attention immediately.
Do not induce vomiting.
Drink large amounts of water or milk, but do not exceed 2 L (2 qt.).
Get medical attention immediately.

block.para: WARNING: Battery posts, terminals, and related accessories contain lead and lead compounds, chemicals known to the State of California to cause cancer and reproductive harm. Wash hands after handling.

caution.para:
Batteries
AVent Tube
Machine must be on a flat surface to accurately check fluid levels. Battery fluid level should be visible at the top of each fill port covering the plates in each cell.

Avoid serious injury or death from explosions. High levels of hydrogen gas can accumulate if the battery box is not vented properly. Always reinstall the vent tubes (A) after performing service or maintenance on the batteries or the battery box. Verify that the ventilation hoses are not bent or kinked.
Replacement batteries must have a ventilation fitting suited for ventilation hose attachment. See your John Deere dealer for replacement batteries equipped with ventilation fittings.
If ventilation tubes are not attached to the battery, then the battery lid must remain off whenever the machine engine is running or whenever the batteries are being charged with an external charger.

BATTERIES ARE NEGATIVE GROUNDED ONLY. Always connect the battery ground strap to the negative (-) posts of the battery. Connect the starter cable to the positive (+) post of the battery. Reversed polarity in the battery or alternator connections results in permanent damage to the electrical system. Connect the ground strap to the negative (-) terminal last.

important.para: Batteries must have same terminal locations.

step.para: Turn off all of the switches and accessories. Clean the battery posts and the terminals.
QUICKLY TAP the ground strap to the negative post. Arcing must not occur. If arcing occurs, DO NOT MAKE CONNECTION. Check to see if the battery position is reversed.
If arcing still occurs, check again that all of the switches and accessories are off. Then, check for shorts, broken wires, and loose or corroded connections.
Connect the negative (-) battery ground straps.

block.head: BatteriesCharging
block.para: Keep the battery fully charged, especially during cold weather. Failure to keep the battery fully charged, above 12.50 V, may result in reduced battery life.

caution.para: Never charge a frozen battery. Thaw at room temperature before connecting to the battery charger. Only charge the batteries in a well ventilated area. Disconnect both cables from the battery terminals when charging the batteries in combine.

important.para: If the batteries are not fully charged, the electrolyte may freeze.

step.para: Determine which battery needs to be charged.
Disconnect both of the battery cables and connect the charger positive cable to the "+" terminal and the charger negative cable to the "-" terminal.
Follow instructions provided with the charger. Always charge the batteries with a 12-volt charger.

caution.para: Checking Battery Specific Gravity Batteries must be on a flat surface to accurately check fluid levels. Battery fluid level should be visible at the top of each fill port covering the plates in each cell.
Battery gas can explode. Keep sparks and flames away from batteries. Use a flashlight to check battery electrolyte level.
Never check the battery charge by placing a metal object across the posts. Use a voltmeter or hydrometer.

step.para: Check specific gravity of the electrolyte in each cell with a battery hydrometer to determine battery condition. Charge battery if reading is below 1.225. Replace battery if difference between cells is more than 0.050.

Always correct specific gravity reading for electrolyte temperature variation. Add 0.004 for every 10F above 80F. (Add 0.007 for every 10C above 27C.) Subtract at the same rate if the electrolyte temperature is below 80F (27C). Corrected specific gravity of a fully charged battery is 1.2651.280.

Battery Connectors
APositive (+) Post BNegative (-) Post
Cold weather starting can be easier by connecting an additional 12 V battery in parallel.

caution.para: Gas given off by batteries is explosive. Avoid sparks near batteries.

important.para: Never connect jumper cables with the key switch or battery disconnect switch ON. Never jump-start with more than 12 V.

step.para: Remove protective caps from posts.

First jumper cable must first be connected to positive (+) post of the booster battery. Connect other end to positive (+) post (A) of the machine battery. Second jumper cable must first be connected to negative (-) post of the booster battery. Connect other end to negative (-) post (B) of the machine battery.

Battery Cover and Cap Screws
ABattery Disconnect Switch BCap Screw CCap Screw DCover
Turn the battery disconnect switch (A) counterclockwise to the OFF position.
Remove cap screws (B) and loosen cap screws (C).
Remove cover (D) to access batteries.

Remove and Install Batteries
APositive Cable BNegative Cable CClamp
Disconnect negative (-) cable (B) from the batteries and the negative jump-start post.
Disconnect positive (+) cable (A) and the positive jump-start post.
Remove clamp (C) and the battery vent tubes.
Clean the batteries and the battery mounting area.
Install the batteries in the battery box and on the plastic tray.
Clean the battery cables and posts and reconnect the battery vent tubes.
Loosely install the clamp (C).
Attach positive (+) cable (A) and the positive jump-start post.
Attach negative (-) cable (B) and the negative jump-start post.
Tighten the battery clamp.
Install the cover and retain with the previously removed cap screws.
Turn the battery disconnect switch clockwise to the ON position.

block.head: Battery Disconnect Switch

important.para:
Battery Disconnect Switch
ABattery Disconnect Switch
Final Tier 4/Stage V: Do not disconnect battery for at least 90 seconds after machine is shut OFF. Selective catalyst reduction (SCR) system automatically purges lines of diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) during this time, immediately after machine is shut OFF. If adequate time is not allowed for lines to be purged, any fluid remaining in lines can crystallize and plug lines. In freezing weather, fluid will freeze and possibly burst lines.

note.para: Turn the battery disconnect switch OFF if the machine is stored longer than 25 days. If the storage period is longer than 90 days, remove the negative lead to the batteries to minimize the load to batteries.

block.para: Turn the battery disconnect switch (A) clockwise to turn ON the machine electrical system or turn the switch counterclockwise to turn OFF the machine electrical system.

note.para:

Press Lights button on navigation bar below display. See Lights Application Help or Operator's Station Help for further information.

step.para: Turn ON the cab headlights (low-beam) (A and C).

note.para: If you have difficulty using the Lights Application, unplug the lights and plug them in as needed.

step.para: Use the Lights Application to turn OFF all the lights except for the left-hand cab headlight (low-beam).

note.para: The light pattern should stop just before the object (B) placed in front of the machine.

step.para: Adjust the left-hand cab headlight (low-beam) to specification. See information later in this section on adjusting the cab headlights.
Turn OFF the left-hand cab headlight (low-beam).
Turn ON the right-hand cab headlight (low-beam) (C).

note.para: The light pattern should stop just before the object (B) placed in front of the machine.

step.para: Adjust the right-hand cab headlight (low-beam) to specification.
Turn ON both cab headlights (low-beam).
Verify that there is a consistent cut-off line from left to right at the 30 m (98 ft) mark. Adjust the cab headlights (low-beam) if needed.

note.para:
Cab Headlights (high beam)
ACab Headlights (low-beam) BCab Headlight (high-beam), Left-Hand CCab Headlight (high-beam), Right-Hand
Press Lights button on navigation bar below display. See Lights Application Help or Operator's Station Help for further information.

step.para: Turn ON both cab headlights (low-beam).

note.para: If you have difficulty using the Lights Application, unplug the lights and plug them in as needed.

step.para: Use the Lights Application to turn OFF all the lights except the cab headlights (low-beam) (A) and the left-hand cab headlight (high-beam) (B).

note.para: The high-beam light pattern should start at approximately 27 m (89 ft) to blend the high- and low-beam headlights together.

step.para: Adjust the left-hand cab headlight (high-beam) to specification. See information later in this section on adjusting the cab headlights.
Turn OFF the left-hand cab headlight (high-beam) (B).
Turn ON the right-hand cab headlight (high-beam) (C).

note.para: The high-beam light pattern should start at approximately 27 m (89 ft) to blend the high- and low-beam headlights together.

step.para: Adjust the right-hand cab headlight (high-beam) to specification.
Turn ON both cab headlights (high-beam) and check the high- and low-beam overlap.

If the cab headlights (high-beam) pattern is too narrow, try rotating the lights outward (horizontally 1 or 2). Adjusting these lights reduces the overlap between the left-hand and right-hand cab headlights (high-beam).

block.head: Cab HeadlightsAdjusting

Headlight Adjustment
ANut BCap Screw
Raise the feeder house, engage the feeder house safety lock, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key before replacing or adjusting the headlights.

note.para: The light assemblies can be adjusted as needed to achieve the correct lighting angles.

block.para: Vertical Adjustment: Loosen nut (A). Rotate the light assembly up or down to desired position and tighten the nut. Repeat on the remaining lights as needed.
Horizontal Adjustment: Loosen cap screw (B). Rotate the light assembly left or right to desired position and tighten the cap screw. Repeat on the remaining lights as needed.

Falling while installing or removing electronic components mounted on equipment can cause serious injury. Use a ladder or platform to easily reach each mounting location. Use sturdy and secure footholds and handholds. Do not install or remove components in wet or icy conditions.

Remove and replace the beacon light assembly.

block.head: Service Tires Safely

caution.para: Explosive separation of a tire and rim parts can cause serious injury or death.
Do not attempt to mount a tire unless you have the proper equipment and experience to perform the job.

block.para: Always maintain the correct tire pressure. Do not inflate the tires above the recommended pressure.
Never weld or heat a wheel and tire assembly. The heat can cause an increase in air pressure resulting in a tire explosion. Welding can structurally weaken or deform the wheel.
When inflating tires, use a clip-on chuck and extension hose long enough to allow you to stand to one side and NOT in front of or over the tire assembly. Use a safety cage if available.
Check wheels for low pressure, cuts, bubbles, damaged rims or missing lug bolts and nuts.

block.head: Tire Loading Decal
block.para:
Tire Loading Decal
ADecal
Decal (A) (located on cab ladder) contains important information concerning tire loading.

block.head: Care and Service of Tires

important.para: Installing tires that do not meet original equipment tire specifications may cause machine malfunction. Consult your dealer or tire supplier for guidance.
Use of substandard tires or larger than recommended tires will void warranty and may decrease stability, affect steering, result in premature tire failure, or cause other durability or safety issues.

block.para: Check tires daily for damage or noticeably low pressure.
At least every 100 hours of operation, check tire pressure. If tires contain liquid ballast, use a special air-water gauge and measure with valve stem at bottom.
A small puncture in a tubeless tire can be temporarily repaired without dismounting the tire, thus avoiding down time during a busy season.
Protect tires from exposure to sunlight, petroleum products, and chemicals.
Drive carefully. Try to avoid rocks and sharp objects.

important.para: A permanent repair should be made as soon as possible to prevent further tire damage.

note.para: Tire information and specifications are based on the latest information available at the time of publication. The right is reserved to make changes at any time without notice. See the online Combine Ag Sales Manual or your John Deere dealer for further information on Tire Pressure Charts.
Tire pressures listed in charts may differ from the tire pressures shown on the side of the tires.
Header compatibility and specified inflation pressures are based on front axle load of a coarse grain configuration.
Load varies based on configuration. This may not reflect the worst case scenario. Consult your local tire dealer if in doubt.
Not all tires are available on all machines or at all manufacturing facilities.
Onboard Air Compressor (if equipped) - not recommended to inflate tires on the machine or run air tools.

block.head: Tire Tread Types

note.para: Tire Tread Types Tire tread shape varies depending on tire manufacture.

block.para: There are three types of tread and these are the most used on agricultural application.

deflist.def: R1 tire. Are most common in agricultural application and suitable for most soil conditions.
R1W tire. The lugs are 20% higher than the R1 tire, providing greater durability when used to run on roads.
R2 tire. Used in land with muddy, wet and with little support. For example, in irrigated rice field.

important.para: All road transportation MUST be done at pressure shown in No Head/Transport column. Improper pressure during transport may decrease vehicle stability. Proper pressure results in better fuel economy and longer tire life.

note.para: See Care and Service of Tires in this section for further information.

entry.para: No Head/ TransportIndicates road transport configuration (no header, no grain in tank).

important.para: All road transportation MUST be done at pressure shown in No Head/Transport column. Improper pressure during transport may decrease vehicle stability. Proper pressure results in better fuel economy and longer tire life.

note.para: See Care and Service of Tires in this section for further information.

entry.para: No Head/ TransportIndicates road transport configuration (no header, no grain in tank).

block.head: Front and Rear Tire Information
block.para: If tires or final drives are changed from what was originally shipped from the factory, it is necessary to recalibrate the system.

important.para: When changing drive wheels, tire radius may also change. POD control unit MUST be set to the new tire radius. See your John Deere dealer for further information on changing the tire codes.
Failure to calibrate system results in inaccurate Harvest Monitor Yields.

block.para: For additional information shown below on front and rear tires, see your John Deere dealer for further information.

block.head: Drive Wheel Starter Stud
block.para: Drive Wheel Starter Stud If a wheel is removed, thread wheel starter stud (HXE16110) into axle, then install wheel. This stud can also be used for duals.

block.head: Drive Wheel Bolt Torque
block.para:
710 Duals Only
All Other Tire Options Each time drive wheels are repositioned or replaced, torque wheel bolts to specification in a crisscross pattern.
Wheel Bolts Torque (dry) 710 Nm (524 lbft)

After the first hour of operation and again after every 10 hours of operation, torque wheel bolts to specification until 50 hours of operation is complete. Torque wheel bolts every 100 hours thereafter.

block.head: Front Drive Wheel Offset

caution.para:
Single Wheel
ADimension BSpindle Surface CTire Centerline
Avoid serious injury or death resulting from final drive failure and loss of drive wheel during transport or field operation. Do not exceed maximum wheel offset.

important.para: Use only John Deere supplied wheels, tires, and spacers. Use of non-John Deere components not meeting specification voids the warranty.
Do not use clamp-on style duals. They do not meet John Deere specification.

block.para:
Wheel offset distance severely affects life of final drive parts. When installing drive wheels, ensure that offset dimension (A) measured from spindle surface (B) to centerline (C) is within specification.
Maximum Wheel Offset
Single Wheel Distance 114.3 mm (4-1/2 in.)

block.object_name: Preparing Dual Wheels for Transport or Service
block.head: Preparing Dual Wheels for Transport or Service

caution.para: Do not attempt to operate machine in the field with outer dual wheels removed. Machine damage can occur.
Only move machine short distances with outer duals removed. Before moving machine reduce machine weight by removing header and emptying grain tank.

important.para: If machine must be transported without outer wheels in place, 5 socket head cap screws and 15 wheel bolts MUST be installed and tightened to specification before lowering front axle to ground. Segmented spacers are omitted for road transport, loading, and unloading.

block.para: When preparing dual wheels for transport, outer wheels can be removed to reduce transport width.
Refer to the following directions whenever the front wheels (outer and inner) need removed or installed on a dual wheel machine. Inner wheel cannot be removed without first removing outer wheel.
Pay close attention to CAUTION statements as they address your safety, the safety of others and safe operations of the machine.

block.head: Jack Point Locations Decal

caution.para:
Jack Point and Tie Down Location Decal
AJack Point Locations Decal
Always empty the grain tank before raising the machine.
Block both sides of the tires to prevent machine movement.

block.para: Jack point locations decal (A) is located on the cab ladder. Decal shows the correct locations for raising the machine using proper jacks.

block.head: Jack Point Locations

caution.para:
Jack Point Locations
AJack Point Location (front) BJack Point Location (rear) CJack Point Location (left) DJack Point Location (right)
Always empty the grain tank before raising the machine.
Block both sides of the tires to prevent machine movement.

note.para: Jack point locations are at the front and the rear of the machine and on the left-hand and right-hand side of the machine.

block.para: Raise the machine at approved jack point locations (AD).

step.para:
Caution
Feeder House Lift Cylinder
Locked/Unlocked
ALock Button BLock Indicator
Raise the feeder house and tilt the hydraulic feeder house fore/aft tilt frame as needed.

note.para: When the feeder house lift cylinder lock button is pulled out, the safety lock indicator (B) may show red. Verify that the safety lock indicator is NOT red before going under the feeder house.

step.para: Push the feeder house safety lock button (A).
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

caution.para:
Blocks
ABlock
Block both sides of tires to prevent movement while raising machine.

step.para: Block front and rear of tires as shown using blocks (A).
With front tires on ground, loosen wheel bolts with one full turn, but do not remove at this time.

caution.para:
Decal
Jack Point
ADecal BJack CJack Point
Jack MUST have a minimum lifting capacity of 10 886 kg (24 000 lb).
Do not raise machine at any location other than at the jack points.
Do not place objects between the jack and the jack point. They may cause machine instability. If the jack does not have enough travel length, place block on ground.
Wood blocks must be in good condition to support machine weight.

note.para: Approved jack point locations can be found on decal (A) on the cab ladder.

step.para: Align jack (B) with the jack point (C) on the front axle and raise machine.

caution.para:
Blocks
ASolid Blocking
To help prevent personal injury caused by unexpected movement of the machine, be sure that machine is stable after blocking.
Do not support machine on cinder blocks, hollow tiles, or props that may crumble under continuous load. Do not work on a machine that is supported solely by a jack.
Wood blocks must be in good condition to support machine weight.
Be sure that the front axle rests on solid blocking before attempting to remove wheels.

step.para: Position solid blocking (A) underneath the front axle. Lower machine onto solid blocking, making sure that no load shift is seen or felt.

caution.para:
Single Wheel Configuration
AWheel Bolt (20 used) BSegmented Spacer (5 used) CWheel
Wheels are heavy and are difficult to handle. To avoid personal injury, two people are needed to remove the wheel.

step.para: Remove four wheel bolts (A) and segmented spacer (B).
Repeat steps as needed for remaining segment spacers and wheels bolts.
Remove wheel (C) away from machine.
Repeat steps as needed on the opposite side of the machine.

caution.para:
Dual Wheel Configuration (Outer Wheel)
AWheel Bolt (20 used) BSegmented Spacer (5 used) CSocket Head Cap Screw (5 used) DOversized Hole (5 used) EOuter Wheel Assembly
Wheels are heavy and are difficult to handle. When handling wheels, off-centered weight can suddenly shift, making wheel handling awkward and the wheel difficult to control. To avoid personal injury, two people are needed to remove the wheel.

step.para: Remove four wheel bolts (A) and segmented spacer (B).
Install one socket head cap screw (C) through the oversized hole (D) to retain inner wheel in place.

caution.para: To avoid personal injury, socket head cap screws MUST be installed to prevent inner wheel from coming off when removing outer wheel.

step.para: Repeat steps as needed for remaining segment spacers and wheels bolts.
Remove outer wheel assembly (E) away from machine.
Repeat steps as needed on the opposite side of the machine.

important.para: If machine must be transported without outer wheels in place, 5 socket head cap screws and 15 wheel bolts MUST be installed and tightened to specification before lowering front axle to ground. Segmented spacers are omitted for road transport, loading, and unloading.

block.head: Using Liquid Weight

caution.para: Valve Stem Installing liquid weight (ballast) requires special equipment and training.

important.para: Cover rim completely with solution to avoid corrosion, but NEVER fill any tire more than 90% full. More solution would leave too little air space to absorb shocks. Damage to tire could occur.

block.para: A solution of water and calcium chloride provides a safe and economical ballast. Used properly, it will not damage tires, tubes, or rims.
Use calcium chloride to prevent water from freezing. A mixture of 1.6 kg (3-1/2 lb) of calcium chloride per 3.8 L (1 gal) will not freeze solid above -45C (-50F).

note.para: Use of alcohol as liquid ballast is not recommended. Calcium chloride solution is heavier and more economical.

block.para: Fill tubeless tires at least to valve level (minimum 75% full). Less solution would expose part of rim, possibly causing corrosion. Tube-type tires may be filled to any level below 90%.

note.para: Ballast requirements vary based on configuration.
Ballast requirements are based off standard Corn Pricing configuration, 133 L (35 gal) fuel in tank, and full grain tank. This may not reflect all scenarios.
Tires requiring fluid must be filled to 75%.

entry.para: No = Ballast not required for any size tires.
Yes = Ballast required for all tire sizes.

caution.para: Folding Button Avoid power line entanglement. Grain tank covers must be closed before transporting machine.

important.para: Verify that grain tank is unloaded before transporting machine on road.
Verify that folding unloading auger and folding grain tank covers are fully folded before driving machine.
Verify tire pressures before transporting machine on the road. See Ground Drive and Rear Axle section for further information.

Follow local regulations for equipment size, lighting, and marking before driving on public roadways.

Remove the radio antenna and place it in the manual storage location compartment located behind the operators seat.

See feeder house safety lock in the feeder house section for further information.

These lights must be turned ON when driving machine on public roadways. Swing cab ladder fully forward to orient marker/hazard lights towards oncoming motorists. Do not operate marker/hazard lights if prohibited by law.

step.para: Turn beacon/hazard light switch ON for both daytime and nighttime road travel. Warning lights automatically operate when hazard lights are ON.
Road Light Switch Use the road light switch to turn ON the road lights for nighttime travel.

note.para: Turn signal indicators on corner post display illuminate to indicate a turn.

step.para: Use turn signals as needed. They are not self-canceling.
Engine Speed (fast speed) Press engine speed switch for maximum engine speed.

caution.para: If transporting machine with header attached, travel at a reasonable speed to ensure adequate braking performance and control of machine.

step.para: Slowly move the multi-function lever forward or rearward. When coming to the top of a hill, pull back on the multi-function lever before starting down the other side.

block.head: Tow Loads Safely
block.para: 32 km/h (20 mph) Maximum Transport Speed while Towing Stopping distance increases with speed and weight of towed loads and on slopes. Towed loads that are too heavy for the combine or are towed too fast can cause loss of control. Consider the total weight of the equipment and its load.
Do not exceed maximum towing capacity of 8000 kg (17 637 lb).
Do not transport at speed exceeding 32 km/h (20 mph) while towing.
Use additional caution and reduce speed when towing under adverse surface conditions, when turning, and on inclines.

Loop
ASafety Chain BHitch Bracket
Avoid possible accident and injury by using a safety chain on towed equipment. Use a safety chain with a strength rating equal to or greater than the gross weight of equipment. Provide only enough slack in the chain to permit turning.

important.para: Never use safety chain for towing or possible damage to machine may result. Safety chain is provided only for transport.

block.para: Route the safety chain (A) through the hitch bracket (B) as shown. Attach the chain back onto itself using the latch-style hook.

Rear Tow Hook

Always use a suitable chain. Do not exceed the breaking strength. Do not mix a chain with tow straps or ropes. Energy stored in the towing device could break and cause serious bodily injury.
