block.object_name: Cleaning Fan Variable Speed Driven-Driver Sheaves (Severe Conditions)
block.head: Cleaning Fan Variable Speed Driven/Driver Sheaves (Severe Conditions)

important.para: Driven Sheaves / Driver Sheaves To prevent damage to the cleaning fan variable speed driven/driver sheaves, do not over grease. Pump 10 shots of grease into each fitting.

note.para: When operating consistently in hilly conditions, grease the cleaning fan variable speed driven/driver sheaves every 50 hours. In normal conditions, grease every 100 hours.

block.para: Close the sheaves (high speed) before greasing. Cycle the fan speed to distribute the grease if operated at constant speed all the time.

block.head: Fuel Precleaner Filter

caution.para:
Style A / Style B
AFuel Precleaner Filter BDrain
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key before performing maintenance work on fuel filters.

block.para: Depending on the machine option, clean or drain fuel precleaner.

item.para: Visually check the fuel precleaner filter (A) and clean if buildup is visible on the screen.
Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove the fuel precleaner filter and clean the screen.
Install the screen and filter.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner to fill.
Close valve on the fuel precleaner.
Inspect the fuel precleaner filter (A).
Open drain (B) to inspect the fuel system for water in the fuel precleaner filter.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner to fill.

step.para:
Water Separator Primary Fuel Filter
ADrain
Check the water separator for water or when diagnostic trouble code is generated.
To remove the water form the water separator bowl, open the drain (A). See MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information.

block.object_name: Rotary Screen, Charge Air Cooler, Oil Cooler, Radiator, Condensers, and Fuel Cooler
block.head: Rotary Screen, Charge Air Cooler, Oil Cooler, Radiator, Condensers, and Fuel Cooler

caution.para:
Radiator and Oil Coolers
ACharge Air Cooler BOil Cooler CRadiator DCondenser EFuel Cooler
Direction of wind, type of crop and its moisture content can all have an effect on where and how much chaff and debris accumulate in the cooling system.

item.para: In heavy debris or windy conditions, clean the cooling system every 10 hours.
In normal harvest conditions, clean the cooling system every 50 hours.

step.para: Clean the following areas from inside out:

item.para: Charge air cooler (A)
Oil cooler (B)
Radiator (C)

step.para: Clean the following areas on the rotary screen door from inside out:

item.para: Condensers (D)
Fuel cooler (E)

note.para: Mass Flow Sensor To lower the grain tank loading auger, remove the bottom support rod hardware.

step.para: Lower the grain tank loading auger.
Clean the mass flow sensor plate.

note.para:
Cab Fresh Air Filter
AKnob BFresh Air Filter
The cab fresh air filter may require cleaning sooner in dusty conditions.

step.para: Turn the knob (A) and lower the access cover.
Remove the fresh air filter (B).
Clean or replace the fresh air filter.

block.head: Moisture Sensor

important.para:
Moisture Sensor
AMoisture Sensor
Static electricity can damage the moisture sensor module. To avoid damage, ensure that a metal surface is touched on the machine with at least one hand or arm before working on or cleaning.
The moisture sensor has internal components that can loosen when dropped, which might not be immediately detectable. Handle the moisture sensor with care when working on or cleaning.

block.para: Remove and clean the moisture sensor (A) when operating in weeds, green crops, or small grains (canola).

item.para: Do not use solvents or other cleaners on the sensor face.
A dry rag is preferred for cleaning. If that does not work, then scrub with only a rag and water.
Do not power wash the moisture sensor face.

block.para: Install the moisture sensor and perform a Moisture Sensor calibration. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.

caution.para:
Bypass Auger
APin (2 used) BEnd Cap CAuger
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove pins (A) and end cap (B).
Remove auger (C) from the moisture sensor bypass.
Clean the auger and area inside the moisture sensor bypass.
Install and align the auger.
Install end cap and retain with pins.

entry.para: Replace Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter

step.para:
Final Drives
ADrain Plug BFill Plug CCheck Hole
Remove the drain plug (A) from the final drive (both sides).
Allow the final drive oil to drain.
Install the drain plug once the oil is drained.
Remove the fill plug (B) from the final drive.
Add oil until the oil level is within 12 mm (1/2 in) of the bottom check hole (C).
Install the previously removed plugs.

Transmission Filter
ATransmission Filter
Remove the transmission filter (A) and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement transmission filter with oil.

Install the transmission filter and tighten to specification.
Transmission Filter Torque 38 Nm (28 lbft)

block.object_name: Main Engine Gear Case-Rotor Lube Filter
block.head: Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter

step.para:
Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter
AMain Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter
Remove the main engine gear case/rotor lube filter (A) and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement main engine gear case/rotor lube filter with oil.

Install the main engine gear case/rotor lube filter and tighten to specification.
Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter Torque 38 Nm (28 lbft)

Transmission Return Filter
AClamp BHose CCap
Loosen clamp (A) and remove the hose (B) from the fitting.
Remove cap (C).
Use the wire handle on the transmission return filter to remove.
Discard the transmission return filter.
Coat the seal on the replacement transmission return filter with oil.
Install the transmission return filter.
Push wire handle down onto the transmission return filter and verify that wire handle locks into place.

Install the previously removed cap and tighten to specification.
Cap Torque 31 Nm (23 lbft)
Install previously removed hose and retain with clamp.

entry.para: Check Tire Pressure and Wheel Bolt Torque
Grease Cleaning Fan Variable Driven/Driver Sheaves (Normal Conditions)

block.head: Tire Pressure and Wheel Bolt Torque
block.para: Tire Check the front and rear tire pressure and the wheel bolt torque. See Ground Drive and Rear Axle section for further information.

block.object_name: Cleaning Fan Variable Speed Driven-Driver Sheaves (Normal Conditions)
block.head: Cleaning Fan Variable Speed Driven/Driver Sheaves (Normal Conditions)

important.para: Driven Sheaves / Driver Sheaves To prevent damage to the cleaning fan variable speed driven/driver sheaves, do not over grease. Pump 10 shots of grease into each fitting.

note.para: When operating consistently in hilly conditions, grease the cleaning fan variable speed driven/driver sheaves every 50 hours. In normal conditions, grease every 100 hours.

block.para: Close the sheaves (high speed) before greasing. Cycle the fan speed to distribute the grease if operated at constant speed all the time.

step.para:
Chain Tensioner
AAccess Door BBushing CEmbossment DNut EWasher FGauge
Open the access door (A) on both sides of the feeder house shield.
One offset link on each chain strand must be removed when bushing (B) aligns with the inner edge of the front embossment (C) as shown.
Tighten nut (D) on both sides of the feeder house until washer (E) is between the end of the gauge (F) and the bottom of the step.
Close the access door on both sides of the feeder house shield.

entry.para: Grease Separator Variable Speed Driven Sheave
Grease Separator Variable Speed Driver Sheave
Grease Front End Variable Speed Driven Sheave (If Equipped)
Grease Front End Variable Speed Driver Sheave (If Equipped)

step.para:
Recirculating Filter
ARecirculating Filter
Remove the cover.
Remove the recirculating filter (A).
Clean or replace the recirculating filter.

important.para:
Driven Sheaves
AFitting (flat surface) BFitting (angled surface)
To prevent damage to the separator variable speed driven sheaves, add only John Deere Corn Head Grease to fitting (A). Add John Deere Multi-Purpose SD Polyurea Grease or John Deere Synthetic Grease to fitting (B). Pump 20 shots of grease into each fitting. Do not over grease fittings.

step.para: To access both fittings, rotate the sheaves.

note.para: Use only John Deere Corn Head Grease when greasing fitting (A). See Fuels and Lubricants section for further information on grease recommendations.

step.para: Grease fitting (A).

note.para: Use only John Deere Multi-Purpose SD Polyurea Grease or John Deere Synthetic Grease when greasing fitting (B). See Fuels and Lubricants section for further information on grease recommendations.

step.para: Grease fitting (B).

block.head: Separator Variable Speed Driver Sheave

important.para: Driver Sheaves To prevent damage to the separator variable speed driver sheaves, do not over grease. Pump 20 shots of grease into the fitting.

note.para: To distribute the grease evenly, start the machine and cycle the separator through the full speed range a couple of times.

block.para: Close the sheaves (high speed) before greasing. If operated at a constant speed all the time, cycle the separator speed to distribute the grease.

block.object_name: Front End Variable Speed Driven Sheave (If Equipped)
block.head: Front End Variable Speed Driven Sheave (If Equipped)

important.para:
Driven Sheaves
AFitting (flat surface) BFitting (angled surface)
To prevent damage to the front end variable speed driven sheaves, add only John Deere Corn Head Grease to fitting (A). Add John Deere Multi-Purpose SD Polyurea Grease or John Deere Synthetic Grease to fitting (B). Pump 20 shots of grease into each fitting. Do not over grease fittings.

step.para: To access both fittings, rotate the sheaves.

note.para: Use only John Deere Corn Head Grease when greasing fitting (A). See Fuels and Lubricants section for further information on grease recommendations.

step.para: Grease fitting (A).

note.para: Use only John Deere Multi-Purpose SD Polyurea Grease or John Deere Synthetic Grease when greasing fitting (B). See Fuels and Lubricants section for further information on grease recommendations.

step.para: Grease fitting (B).

block.object_name: Front End Variable Speed Driver Sheave (If Equipped)

important.para: Driver Sheaves To prevent damage to the front end variable speed driver sheaves, do not over grease. Pump 20 shots of grease into the fitting.

note.para: To distribute the grease evenly, start the machine and cycle the separator through the full speed range a couple of times.

block.para: Close the sheaves (high speed) before greasing. If operated at a constant speed all the time, cycle the separator speed to distribute the grease.

entry.para: Grease Vertical Unloading Auger Upper Gear Case
Grease Feeder House Dust Fan (If Equipped)

block.head: Unloading Auger Elbow Gear Case

important.para: Grease Fitting To prevent damage to the unloading auger elbow gear case, do no over grease. Pump 20 shots of grease into the fitting.

block.para: Grease the fitting.

block.object_name: Vertical Unloading Auger Upper Gear Case
block.head: Vertical Unloading Auger Upper Gear Case

important.para: Grease Fittings To prevent damage to the vertical unloading auger upper gear case, do no over grease. Pump 20 shots of grease into the fittings.

block.para: Grease the fittings.

step.para:
Final Drive
APlug
Remove the plug (A) and check the oil level (both sides).
The oil level should be within 12 mm (1/2 in) of the bottom of the hole.
Add oil as needed.
Install the previously removed plug.

Chopper Gear Case
ALatch BDrain Plug CFill Plug DSight Glass
Release latch (A) and rotate shield to open.
Remove the drain plug (B) from the two-speed chopper gear case.
Allow the two-speed chopper gear case oil to drain.
Install the drain plug once the oil is drained.

Tighten the drain plug to specification.
Drain Plug Torque 30 Nm (22 lbft)
Remove the fill plug (C) from the two-speed chopper gear case.

note.para: See Fuels and Lubricants section for oil recommendations and see Specifications section for oil capacity.

step.para: Add oil until the oil level is visible at sight glass (D).

Tighten the fill plug to specification.
Fill Plug Torque 30 Nm (22 lbft)

Chopper Gear Case Handle
AShifter Handle BSlow-Speed Position CHigh-Speed Position
Move the chopper shifter handle (A) to the opposite speed. Example: slow-speed position (B) to high-speed position (C) or high-speed position (C) to slow-speed position (B).
Start the machine and run the separator for a maximum of 1 minute.
Shut OFF the engine and let the machine sit for 5 minutes, allowing the air to settle from the two-speed chopper gear case.
Verify that oil is visible at sight glass.
Add oil as needed until the oil level is visible at the center of sight glass.

note.para: It may be necessary to rotate sheave a small amount while moving shifter handle.

step.para: Move the chopper shifter handle back to the original speed position.

important.para:
Feeder House Dust Fan
AAccess Door BFitting
To prevent damage to the feeder house dust fan, do not over grease. Pump 10 shots of grease into the fitting.

step.para: Remove the access door (A) on the feeder house dust fan.
Grease fitting (B).
Install the access door on the feeder house dust fan.

entry.para: Check Loading Auger Fixed Gear Case Oil
Check Loading Auger Pivoting Gear Case Oil
Clean Moisture Sensor Bypass Auger (If Required)

Replace ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company Clean Grain Elevator Camera and Tailings System Camera Desiccant Cartridge (If Equipped)If the harvest season is complete, wait until the beginning of the next harvest season to extend the desiccant cartridge life.

step.para: Batteries Remove the battery box cover.
Clean the top of the batteries.
Visually check the water level in each cell.

note.para: Water level must be at the bottom of each filler neck.

step.para: If needed, fill each cell with distilled water.
Clean the battery posts, cables, and tighten the connections as needed.

caution.para:
Fire Extinguisher
AFire Extinguisher
Inspect fire extinguisher straps and mounting hardware at least once a year. If fire extinguisher straps or mounting hardware show any sign of damage, or unusual wear, discoloration or abrasion, the entire strap and hardware must be replaced. For your safety, replace fire extinguisher components with replacement parts approved for your machine. See your John Deere dealer.

step.para: Inspect the fire extinguishers (A) by following the maintenance instructions on the fire extinguisher label.
Recharge or replace as necessary.

block.head: Seat Belts

caution.para: Seat Belt Inspect the seat belt and mounting hardware at least once a year. If the seat belt system, including mounting hardware, buckle, belt, or retractor, shows any sign of damage or unusual wear, discoloration, or abrasion, the entire seat belt must be replaced. Replace the seat belt system only with replacement parts approved for your machine. See your John Deere dealer for further information.

block.para: Inspect seat belt (operator's seat and instructional seat) for damage.

Loading Auger Fixed Gear Case
ADipstick
Loading auger gear case does not need drained.

step.para: Remove dipstick (A) and check oil level.
Add oil as needed.

Loading Auger Pivoting Gear Case
ADipstick
Loading auger gear case does not need drained.

Add oil as needed.

important.para: Air Filter Elements To prevent engine damage, only service the primary air filter when the air filter restricted icon is displayed on the armrest display.

step.para: Remove the primary air filter and service.
Check the safety filter for plugging.
Check for leaks and for collapse of the aspirator tube.

block.head: Moisture Sensor

important.para:
Moisture Sensor
AMoisture Sensor
Static electricity can damage the moisture sensor module. To avoid damage, ensure that a metal surface is touched on the machine with at least one hand or arm before working on or cleaning.
The moisture sensor has internal components that can loosen when dropped, which might not be immediately detectable. Handle the moisture sensor with care when working on or cleaning.

block.para: Remove and clean the moisture sensor (A) when operating in weeds, green crops, or small grains (canola).

item.para: Do not use solvents or other cleaners on the sensor face.
A dry rag is preferred for cleaning. If that does not work, then scrub with only a rag and water.
Do not power wash the moisture sensor face.

block.para: Install the moisture sensor and perform a Moisture Sensor calibration. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.

caution.para:
Bypass Auger
APin (2 used) BEnd Cap CAuger
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove pins (A) and end cap (B).
Remove auger (C) from the moisture sensor bypass.
Clean the auger and area inside the moisture sensor bypass.
Install and align the auger.
Install end cap and retain with pins.

caution.para:
Cover Plate
AHex Socket Screw (4 used) BCover Plate
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: Crop material and other debris may accumulate around the desiccant cartridge. Inspect and clean the area around the desiccant cartridge before removing.

note.para: The ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company clean grain elevator camera is shown. The ActiveVision tailings system camera is similar.
Replace the desiccant cartridge as needed when the moisture buildup is visible on the interior of the camera lens.
If the harvest season is complete, wait until the beginning of the next harvest season to extend the desiccant cartridge life.

step.para: Remove hex socket screws (A) and cover plate (B).

Desiccant Container (tool)
ADesiccant Container (tool) BNotch CDesiccant Cartridge
Align the desiccant container (A) that was included with the replacement desiccant cartridge with notch (B).

important.para: Do not allow crop material to enter into the ActiveVision camera when replacing the desiccant cartridge.

step.para: Remove the desiccant cartridge (C) from the ActiveVision camera.
Discard the desiccant cartridge.

Desiccant Container (tool) and Desiccant Cartridge
ADesiccant Container (tool) BDesiccant Cartridge
Remove the desiccant container (A) from the replacement desiccant cartridge (B).
Install the desiccant cartridge into the ActiveVision camera.
Align the desiccant tool with the notch.

Tighten the desiccant cartridge until it is hand-tight or to specification.
Desiccant Cartridge Torque 5 Nm (44 lbin)
Install the cover plate over the desiccant cartridge.
Apply threadlock and sealer (medium strength) to hex socket screws.

Tighten the hex socket screws to specification.
Hex Socket Screws Torque 2.5 Nm (22 lbin)

entry.para: Replace Primary and Secondary Fuel Filter
Replace Fuel Precleaner Filter (Heavy-Duty Option) (Style B)
Inspect Fuel Tank Breather (Fast Fill Fuel System) (If Equipped)
Inspect Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank Breather (Final Tier 4/Stage V)

important.para:
Filter / Drain / Cap and Dipstick
AOil Filter BDrain Valve CCap DDipstick
Change the oil every 250 hours when using other engine oils as specified in Fuels and Lubricants section.
Change the oil every 500 hours when using John Deere Plus-50Plus-50 is a trademark of Deere & Company II engine oil and a John Deere filter. See Fuels and Lubricants section for further information.
Final Tier 4/Stage V engines require Plus-50 II engine oil or API CK-4, API CJ-4, ACEA E9, ACEA E6 certified oils.
Use only ultra-low sulfur diesel (ULSD) fuel with a maximum sulfur content of 15 mg/kg (15 ppm).

step.para: Remove and replace the oil filter (A).
To remove the oil, open the drain valve (B).
To fill the oil, remove the cap (C).
Check the oil level after filling with dipstick (D).
Start the machine to cycle the oil through the oil filter and engine.
The oil level should be at the "FULL" mark on the dipstick (D).

note.para: For the most accurate oil level reading, check the engine oil when the engine has been off for at least 90 minutes and the machine is parked on level ground. An oil level reading within the cross-hatch area is acceptable.

caution.para:
Primary Filter
APrimary Fuel Filter BFilter Slot (2 used) CHousing Tab (2 used)
High-pressure fluid remaining in fuel lines can cause serious injury. Before disconnecting the fuel lines, sensors, or any other components between the high-pressure fuel pump and nozzles, wait a minimum of 15 minutes after the engine is stopped.
Before performing maintenance work on the fuel filter, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove and replace the primary fuel filter (A) when performance decline is noticed or diagnostic trouble code is generated.
Disconnect the water sensor (if equipped).
Remove the fuel from the filter and discard.
Lubricate the replacement primary fuel filter seal with a thin film of oil or fuel.
Align the filter slots (B) on the primary fuel filter with housing tabs (C).
Install and tighten the primary fuel filter until it is hand-tight.
Tighten primary fuel filter by an additional 1/2 turn.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner.
To prime the fuel system, turn the key switch to the ON position. See MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information.

Secondary Fuel Filter
ASecondary Fuel Filter BFilter Slot (2 used) CHousing Tab (2 used)
Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove and replace the secondary fuel filter (A) when performance decline is noticed or diagnostic trouble code is generated.
Remove the fuel from the filter and discard.
Lubricate the replacement secondary fuel filter seal with a thin film of oil or fuel.
Align the filter slots (B) on the secondary fuel filter with housing tabs (C).
Install and tighten the secondary fuel filter until it is hand-tight.
Tighten secondary fuel filter by one additional full turn.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner.
To prime the fuel system, turn the key switch to the ON position. See MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information.

caution.para:
Fuel Precleaner Filter
AFuel Precleaner Filter
Before performing maintenance work on the fuel precleaner filter, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove the fuel precleaner filter (A) and clean the screen.
Install the screen and fuel precleaner filter.
To fill the bowl, open the valve on the fuel precleaner.

caution.para:
Fuel Precleaner Filter (Heavy-Duty)
AFuel Precleaner Filter
Before performing maintenance work on the fuel precleaner filter, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove and replace the fuel precleaner filter (A) when performance decline is noticed or diagnostic trouble code is generated.
Remove the fuel from the filter and discard.
Install the replacement fuel precleaner filter.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner.

important.para:
Fuel Tank Breather
AFuel Tank Breather
To prevent fuel tank damage, do not allow debris to collect on the breather.

step.para: Visually inspect the fuel tank breather (A).
Remove the fuel tank breather and clean.

block.head: Fuel Tank Breather (Fast Fill Fuel System) (If Equipped)

Fuel Tank Breather (Fast Fill)

To prevent fuel tank damage, do not allow debris to collect on the breather.

step.para: Visually inspect the fuel tank breather (A).

entry.para: Replace Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter
Replace Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter

block.object_name: Change Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter
block.head: Change Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter

step.para:
Cover
ACover
Remove cover (A).

caution.para:
DEF Dosing Unit Filter
AFilter Cover BEqualizing Element CFilter Tool DDEF Dosing Unit Filter
Avoid contact with eyes. If contact occurs, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. Reference the Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

Spilled DEF, if left to dry or if only wiped away with a cloth, leaves a white residue. Improperly cleaned DEF spill can interfere with diagnosis of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system leakage problems.

note.para: The DEF dosing unit filter and DEF in-line filter must be replaced together every 1500 hours or 36 months, whichever occurs first.
Servicing DEF dosing unit filter requires removing extra covers or components. See Access DEF Dosing Unit for location information.

step.para: Clear all debris from area around the DEF dosing unit.

note.para: Wait approximately 5 minutes for DEF to purge from the system.

step.para: Remove filter cover (A).
Remove and discard the equalizing element (B).

note.para: Filter tool (C) is supplied with the replacement filter.

step.para: Insert black end of the filter tool (C) into the DEF dosing unit filter (D) until a CLICK is felt or heard, indicating that the filter tool is fully engaged.

note.para: A tool, such as a screwdriver, can be inserted into the filter tool slot to assist removal.

step.para: Pull filter tool and DEF dosing unit filter from the DEF dosing unit. Discard DEF dosing unit filter and filter tool.
Clean DEF dosing unit threads and mating surfaces with distilled water.
Lubricate DEF filter O-rings with clean DEF. Carefully insert DEF dosing unit filter into the DEF dosing unit.
Install new DEF dosing unit filter equalizing element into the DEF dosing unit filter.

Install filter cover and tighten to specification.
Filter Cover Torque 23 Nm (204 lbin)
Install previously removed cover.

block.object_name: Replace Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter
block.head: Replace Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter

caution.para:
Plug and Filter Cover
ADrain Plug BFilter Cover
Avoid contact with eyes. If contact occurs, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. Reference the Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

Spilled DEF, if left to dry or if only wiped away with a cloth, leaves a white residue. Improperly cleaned DEF spill can interfere with diagnosis of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system leakage problems.

note.para: The DEF in-line filter and DEF dosing unit filter must be replaced together every 1500 hours or 36 months, whichever occurs first.

step.para: Clear all debris from area around in-line DEF filter assembly.

note.para: Wait approximately 5 minutes for DEF to purge from the system.

step.para: Remove and discard drain plug (A).
Drain DEF fluid into a proper container.
Remove filter cover (B).

Filter Assembly
AFilter Assembly BFilter
Pull filter assembly (A) down from the DEF body.

note.para: If necessary, tap filter to loosen. Plastic tabs inside the filter cover lock the filter into place.

step.para: Remove and discard filter (B) from filter cover.
Clean assembly threads and mating surfaces with distilled water.

Filter Assembly Components
AFoam Spacer BSeal CFilter Cover
Remove and discard foam spacer (A) and discard seal (B) from filter cover (C).
Install replacement foam spacer and replacement seal into previously removed filter cover.

note.para:
Filter Assembly
AFilter BDEF Body
Plastic tabs inside the cover lock the filter into place.

step.para: Insert replacement filter (A) into filter cover as shown, then into the DEF body (B).

Install filter cover and tighten to specification.
Filter Cover Torque 25 Nm (221 lbin)

O-Ring and Drain Plug
AO-Ring BNotch
Install replacement O-ring (A) into notch (B) on the replacement drain plug.

Install drain plug into filter cover and tighten to specification.
Drain Plug Torque 4 Nm (35 lbin)

entry.para: Change Hydraulic System Oil and Replace Hydraulic Filters

item.para: B - Hydraulic Reservoir Drain Valve
C - Engine Gear Case Hydraulic Oil Drain
D - Transmission Drain Plug
E - Hydrostatic Cooler Return Filter
F - Auxiliary Hydraulic Return Filter
G - Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter
H - Hydrostatic Charge Filter
I - Transmission Filter
J - Hydraulic Reservoir Cap
K - Hydraulic Reservoir Fitting

step.para:
Final Drives
ADrain Plug BFill Plug CCheck Hole
Remove the drain plug (A) from the final drive (both sides).
Allow the final drive oil to drain.
Install the drain plug once the oil is drained.
Remove the fill plug (B) from the final drive.
Add oil until the oil level is within 12 mm (1/2 in) of the bottom check hole (C).
Install the previously removed plugs.

block.object_name: Hydraulic System Oil and Hydraulic Filters
block.head: Hydraulic System Oil and Hydraulic Filters

step.para:
Hydraulic Reservoir Drain Valve
ADrain Valve
Fully lower feeder house to the ground to retract the hydraulic lift cylinders and shut OFF engine.

important.para: To prevent system contamination, clean hydraulic reservoir area.

step.para: Install a drain hose onto the hydraulic reservoir drain valve (A).
To drain the hydraulic oil, open the hydraulic reservoir drain valve.
Close the hydraulic reservoir drain valve once the hydraulic oil is drained.

Main Engine Gear Case Drain
AHydraulic Cap
Remove the hydraulic cap (A) from the main engine gear case drain tube.
Allow the main engine gear case hydraulic oil to drain.
Install the hydraulic cap onto the main engine gear case drain tube once the hydraulic oil is drained.

Transmission Drain Plug
ADrain Plug
Remove the transmission drain plug (A).
Allow the transmission hydraulic oil to drain.
Install the plug in the transmission once the hydraulic oil is drained.

Hydrostatic Cooler Return Filter
AFilter Bowl
Remove the filter bowl (A).
Remove the hydrostatic cooler return filter and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement hydrostatic cooler return filter with oil.
Install the replacement hydrostatic cooler return filter.

Install the previously removed filter bowl and tighten to specification.
Filter Bowl Torque 41 Nm (30 lbft)

Auxiliary Hydraulic Return Filter
ADrain Plug BFilter Bowl
Remove the drain plug (A) from the bottom of the filter bowl (B).
Allow the filter bowl hydraulic oil to drain.
Install the plug in the filter bowl once the hydraulic oil is drained.
Remove the filter bowl.
Remove the auxiliary hydraulic return filter and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement auxiliary hydraulic return filter with oil.
Install and tighten the replacement auxiliary hydraulic return filter until it is hand-tight.

Install the previously removed filter bowl and tighten to specification.
Filter Bowl Torque 50 Nm (37 lbft)

Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter
AMain Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter
Remove the main engine gear case/rotor lube filter (A) and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement main engine gear case/rotor lube filter with oil.

Install the main engine gear case/rotor lube filter and tighten to specification.
Main Engine Gear Case/Rotor Lube Filter Torque 38 Nm (28 lbft)

Hydrostatic Charge Filter
AHydrostatic Charge Filter
Remove the hydrostatic charge filter (A) and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement hydrostatic charge filter with oil.

Install the hydrostatic charge filter and tighten to specification.
Hydrostatic Charge Filter Torque 38 Nm (28 lbft)

Transmission Filter
ATransmission Filter
Remove the transmission filter (A) and discard.
Coat the seal on the replacement transmission filter with oil.

Install the transmission filter and tighten to specification.
Transmission Filter Torque 38 Nm (28 lbft)

Transmission Return Filter
AClamp BHose CCap
Loosen clamp (A) and remove the hose (B) from the fitting.
Remove cap (C) from the hydraulic reservoir.
Use the wire handle on the transmission return filter to remove.
Discard the transmission return filter.
Coat the seal on the replacement transmission return filter with oil.
Install the transmission return filter.

note.para: Verify that wire handle locks into place.

step.para: Push wire handle down onto the transmission return filter.

Install the previously removed cap and tighten to specification.
Cap Torque 31 Nm (23 lbft)

Hydraulic Reservoir
AClamp BHose CFitting
Loosen clamp (A) and remove the hose (B).
Remove fitting (C) from the hydraulic reservoir.
Add hydraulic oil to the hydraulic reservoir through hole opening. See Fuels and Lubricants section for oil recommendations.

Main Engine Gear Case Dipstick
ADipstick
Add oil until the oil level is at the "ADD" mark on the dipstick (A). See Fuels and Lubricants section for oil recommendations.
Install previously removed dipstick.

Hydraulic Reservoir
AClamp BHose CFitting
Install previously removed fitting (C) into the hydraulic reservoir.
Install previously removed hose (B) and retain with previously removed clamp (A).

important.para: To prevent hydraulic damage, do no let the engine run longer than 1 minute.

step.para: Start the machine and run the engine for a maximum of 1 minute.
Shut OFF the engine and let the machine sit for 5 minutes, allowing the air to settle from the hydraulic oil.
Remove the main engine gear case dipstick and check the oil level.
Add oil through the main engine gear case fill tube until the oil level is at the "FULL" mark on the dipstick.
Repeat the procedures as needed until the oil level remains at the "FULL" mark on the main engine gear case dipstick.

block.object_name: Service Interval Chart-Every 6000 Hours or Six Years
block.head: Service Interval ChartEvery 6000 Hours or Six Years

note.para: SCHEDULED coolant change interval is six years or 6000 hours if John Deere Cool-GardCool-Gard is a trademark of Deere & Company II or Cool-Gard II PG is used.

table.caption: Service Interval ChartEvery 6000 Hours or Six Years

note.para:
Radiator Drain and Surge Tank
ADrain BSurge Tank
When Cool-GardCool-Gard is a trademark of Deere & Company II or Cool-Gard II PG is used, the drain interval is six years or 6000 hours of operation.
If a coolant other than Cool-Gard II or Cool-Gard II PG is used, reduce the drain interval to two years or 2000 hours of operation.

step.para: Open the drain (A) on the radiator.

Flush and refill the surge tank (B) with the correct coolant and conditioner. See MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information. See Fuels and Lubricants section for coolant recommendations.
Check the engine coolant level in the surge tank with the engine cold. The level must be up to the "Max Cold" line.

entry.para: Clean ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company Clean Grain Elevator Camera (If Equipped)

Replace ActiveVision Clean Grain Elevator Camera Desiccant Cartridge (If Equipped)If the harvest season is complete, wait until the beginning of the next harvest season to extend the desiccant cartridge life.
Clean ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company Tailings System Camera (If Equipped)

Replace ActiveVision Tailings System Camera Desiccant Cartridge (If Equipped)If the harvest season is complete, wait until the beginning of the next harvest season to extend the desiccant cartridge life.
Inspect Fire Extinguisher Bracket Straps (If Equipped)

step.para:
Recirculating Filter
ARecirculating Filter
Remove the cover.
Remove the recirculating filter (A).
Clean or replace the recirculating filter.

note.para:
Cab Fresh Air Filter
AKnob BFresh Air Filter
The cab fresh air filter may require cleaning sooner in dusty conditions.

step.para: Turn the knob (A) and lower the access cover.
Remove the fresh air filter (B).
Clean or replace the fresh air filter.

Windshield Washer Reservoir
ACap
Open the cap (A).
Fill the windshield washer reservoir.

block.head: Alternator Screen
block.para: Alternator Screen Clean the screen when it is 50% covered with debris.

block.head: Moisture Sensor

important.para:
Moisture Sensor
AMoisture Sensor
Static electricity can damage the moisture sensor module. To avoid damage, ensure that a metal surface is touched on the machine with at least one hand or arm before working on or cleaning.
The moisture sensor has internal components that can loosen when dropped, which might not be immediately detectable. Handle the moisture sensor with care when working on or cleaning.

block.para: Remove and clean the moisture sensor (A) when operating in weeds, green crops, or small grains (canola).

item.para: Do not use solvents or other cleaners on the sensor face.
A dry rag is preferred for cleaning. If that does not work, then scrub with only a rag and water.
Do not power wash the moisture sensor face.

block.para: Install the moisture sensor and perform a Moisture Sensor calibration. See Calibrations Application Help or Operators Station Help for further information.

caution.para:
Bypass Auger
APin (2 used) BEnd Cap CAuger
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Remove pins (A) and end cap (B).
Remove auger (C) from the moisture sensor bypass.
Clean the auger and area inside the moisture sensor bypass.
Install and align the auger.
Install end cap and retain with pins.

block.object_name: ActiveVision Clean Grain Elevator Camera (If Equipped)
block.head: ActiveVision Clean Grain Elevator Camera (If Equipped)

note.para:
Clean Grain Elevator Camera
AActiveVision Clean Grain Elevator Camera
The cleaning frequency varies depending on several factors, including operating conditions, weather, and crop conditions. Clean the camera lens using a clean, soft, moistened cloth.

block.para: Open the latch and clean the ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company clean grain elevator camera (A).

block.head: ActiveVision Tailings System Camera (If Equipped)

note.para:
Tailings System Camera
AActiveVision Tailings System Camera
The cleaning frequency varies depending on several factors, including operating conditions, weather, and crop conditions. Clean the camera lens using a clean, soft, moistened cloth.

block.para: Open the latch and clean the ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company tailings system camera (A).

caution.para:
Cover Plate
AHex Socket Screw (4 used) BCover Plate
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: Crop material and other debris may accumulate around the desiccant cartridge. Inspect and clean the area around the desiccant cartridge before removing.

note.para: The ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company clean grain elevator camera is shown. The ActiveVision tailings system camera is similar.
Replace the desiccant cartridge as needed when the moisture buildup is visible on the interior of the camera lens.
If the harvest season is complete, wait until the beginning of the next harvest season to extend the desiccant cartridge life.

step.para: Remove hex socket screws (A) and cover plate (B).

Desiccant Container (tool)
ADesiccant Container (tool) BNotch CDesiccant Cartridge
Align the desiccant container (A) that was included with the replacement desiccant cartridge with notch (B).

important.para: Do not allow crop material to enter into the ActiveVision camera when replacing the desiccant cartridge.

step.para: Remove the desiccant cartridge (C) from the ActiveVision camera.
Discard the desiccant cartridge.

Desiccant Container (tool) and Desiccant Cartridge
ADesiccant Container (tool) BDesiccant Cartridge
Remove the desiccant container (A) from the replacement desiccant cartridge (B).
Install the desiccant cartridge into the ActiveVision camera.
Align the desiccant tool with the notch.

Tighten the desiccant cartridge until it is hand-tight or to specification.
Desiccant Cartridge Torque 5 Nm (44 lbin)
Install the cover plate over the desiccant cartridge.
Apply threadlock and sealer (medium strength) to hex socket screws.

Tighten the hex socket screws to specification.
Hex Socket Screws Torque 2.5 Nm (22 lbin)

block.head: Fire Extinguisher Bracket Straps (If Equipped)

caution.para:
Fire Extinguishers
AFire Extinguisher
Inspect fire extinguisher straps and mounting hardware at least once a year. If fire extinguisher straps or mounting hardware show any sign of damage or unusual wear, discoloration, or abrasion, the entire strap and hardware must be replaced. For your safety, replace fire extinguisher components with replacement parts approved for your machine. See your John Deere dealer.

block.para: Inspect the fire extinguisher (A) bracket straps.

block.head: Clean Windows, Mirrors, and Lights
block.para: Be sure that there is good visibility in all directions. Clean windows, mirrors, and lights to ensure good visibility.

item.para: Do not use solvents or other cleaners. John Deere Glass Cleaner or equivalent is recommended.
A soft, non-abrasive rag or towel is preferred for cleaning.

entry.para: A qualified repair shop or person of the owner's choosing may maintain, replace, or repair emission control devices and systems with original or equivalent replacement parts. However, warranty, recall, and all other services paid for by John Deere must be performed at an authorized John Deere service center.

caution.para:
Rear Ladder
ALatch BHandle
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Turn latch (A) to unlock the ladder.
Use handle (B) to lower/raise the ladder fully.

Handrail
ALockout Pin BHandrail
Pull lockout pin (A) and rotate handrail (B) up until handrail locks into place.
Open engine access covers.

caution.para:
Starting Fluid Can
AStarting Fluid Can
Starting fluid is highly flammable and can cause injury or death to you or others if accidentally ignited. DO NOT use near fire, sparks, or flames. Read the cautionary information on the container and protect the container against damage.

step.para: Open the engine access cover. Remove the safety cap and spray button from starting fluid can (A). Loosen the thumb wheel enough to change the cans and then tighten.

important.para: To avoid drawing dust into the engine, always keep the can in position.

step.para: Protect the starting fluid can from extreme heat or damage.
Check for fluid and valve operation by installing and pressing the spray nozzle. If no fluid sprays out, replace the can.

caution.para: To prevent possible injury from exploding container, do not carry extra or empty cans inside cab.

block.object_name: Do Not Modify Engine Power or Fuel-Air System
block.head: Do Not Modify Engine Power or Fuel/Air System

important.para: Increasing horsepower, or altering any aspect of fuel and air delivery on emissions certified engines beyond factory settings, will cause emission levels beyond what is allowed by engine emission regulations. Unauthorized adjustments are in violation of the emission regulations applicable to this engine and may result in substantial fines and penalties. Machine warranty will be voided if power level is changed from factory specifications.
Do not attempt to service injection pump or fuel injectors. Special training and special tools are required. See your John Deere dealer.

caution.para: Fuel System Escaping diesel fuel under pressure can penetrate the skin causing serious injury. Relieve pressure before disconnecting hydraulic or other lines. Tighten all connections before applying pressure. Keep hands and body away from pin holes and nozzles which eject fluids under high pressure. Use a piece of cardboard or paper to search for leaks. Do not use your hand.
If ANY fluid is injected into the skin, it must be surgically removed within a few hours by a doctor familiar with this type injury or gangrene may result.

block.head: Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) TankFilling

caution.para:
Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank Cap and Breather
ACap BDiesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank Breather
Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) contains urea. Do not get fluid in eyes. In case of contact, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. In the event DEF is ingested, contact a physician immediately. Reference Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: Using incorrect or unapproved aftertreatment components can damage the vehicles aftertreatment system and reduce ability of the aftertreatment system to function correctly.

note.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

block.para: Cap (A) is not vented. Excess air is vented through Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) tank breather (B).

Visually inspect the breather. Do not allow excessive amounts of chaff or debris to collect on the breather. If the breather is covered with debris, it does not allow the tank to breathe. Remove the breather from the hose and clean.

Fill tank every time the machine is refueled. If this cannot be done, monitor the Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) level indicator on the corner post display and refill as necessary. To avoid drastic changes in the machine performance, always keep the fluid level above the topmost red mark on the level indicator. See Combine Overview Application Help or Operators Station for further information.
To fill tank:

item.para: Wash and rinse containers with distilled water to remove contaminants before adding the fluid.
Wipe area around the cap before removing to reduce the chance of contaminating fluid.
Using a funnel, carefully pour the fluid into the tank, watching the level through the sight glass.
Install the previously removed cap.
Carefully clean any spills using distilled water.

caution.para:
Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank Drain Valve
AFitting BHandle
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

important.para: Long-term storage of fluids in the vehicle (over 12 months) is not recommended. If long-term storage is necessary, periodic testing of the fluid is recommended to ensure that the urea concentration does not fall out of specification.

If an unapproved fluid, such as diesel fuel or engine coolant is added, drain the tank and rinse with distilled water, then refill the tank. If the system does not operate correctly after cleaning and refilling, contact your John Deere dealer to determine how to clean and purge the system. If water has been added to the tank, drain tank, flush with distilled water, and refill with Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF). Check the concentration of fluid after filling the tank. See Fuels and Lubricants section for testing.

note.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. Fluid is corrosive to painted surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

step.para: Attach a hose to the fitting (A) at the bottom of the tank.
Use handle (B) to open the drain valve.
Close the drain valve and remove the hose once the fluid is drained.

block.object_name: Access Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter
block.head: Access Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter

caution.para: Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter Avoid contact with eyes. In case of contact, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. Reference the Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

Spilled DEF, if left to dry or if only wiped away with a cloth, leaves a white residue. Improperly cleaned DEF spill can interfere with diagnosis of Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system leakage problems.

step.para: Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Remove and replace the diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) dosing unit filter. See Change Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Dosing Unit Filter for further information.

block.object_name: Access Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter
block.head: Access Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter

caution.para: Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter Avoid contact with eyes. In case of contact, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. Reference the Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

Spilled DEF, if left to dry or if only wiped away with a cloth, leaves a white residue. Improperly cleaned DEF spill can interfere with diagnosis of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system leakage problems.

step.para: Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.
Remove and replace the diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) in-line filter. See Replace Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) In-Line Filter for further information.

block.head: Cleaning Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank

caution.para: Avoid contact with eyes. In case of contact, immediately flush eyes with large amounts of water for a minimum of 15 minutes. Reference the Materials Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional information.

important.para: If DEF is spilled or contacts any surface other than the storage tank, immediately clean the surface with clear water. DEF is corrosive to painted and unpainted metallic surfaces and can distort some plastic and rubber components.

Spilled DEF, if left to dry or if only wiped away with a cloth, leaves a white residue. Improperly cleaned DEF spill can interfere with diagnosis of Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system leakage problems.

block.para: If foreign material or fluid has been added to the DEF tank, drain the DEF tank, flush, and fill with new DEF.

If DEF quality is in question, pull a sample out of the DEF tank and place into a clear container. DEF should be crystal clear with a light ammonia smell. If DEF appears cloudy, has a colored tint, or has a profound ammonia smell, it is likely not within specification. DEF in this condition should not be used.

step.para: Remove drain plug (if equipped), and drain or siphon bad DEF from DEF tank.

note.para: Cleaning can take place with DEF tank installed or removed.

step.para: Clean DEF tank with new DEF.

DEF must pass visual, smell, and concentration checks before running the engine. See Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) For Use In Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) Equipped Engines in the Fuels, Lubricants, and Coolants Section for more information.
Drain or siphon DEF tank.

note.para: Repeat steps 23 until DEF tank has been cleaned.

step.para: Early version: Change DEF dosing unit filter and DEF tank header suction screen.
Later version: Change DEF dosing unit filter and DEF inline filter.
If removed, install DEF tank drain plug.
If removed, install DEF tank.
Fill DEF tank with new DEF.

Check DEF concentration with DEF refractometer, such as JDG11594 or JDG11684. The correct DEF concentration is 31.8% 33.2%. See your authorized dealer for more information. DEF Digital Refractometer JDG11594 Used to test the DEF concentration. Region 2 dealers: Order JDG11684 DEF Refractometer JDG11684 Used to test the DEF concentration.
If DEF is not within specification, does not appear clear, or does not have a slight ammonia smell, contact your authorized dealer.

caution.para:
Fuel Tank Cap and Breather
AFuel Tank Cap BFuel Tank Breather
Handle fuel carefully. Do not refuel the machine while smoking. Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key before filling tank.

Do not overfill the fuel tank. Bodily injury can result from fuel splash back. Leakage can result from expansion of the fuel. If the tank is too full and the temperature gets too hot (such as from being left in direct sunlight) the tank will overflow.

step.para: Fuel tank cap (A) is not vented. Excess air is vented through the fuel tank breather (B).

Visually inspect the fuel tank breather. Do not allow excessive amounts of chaff or debris to collect on the breather. If the breather is covered with debris, it does not allow the fuel tank to breathe. Remove the fuel tank breather from the hose and clean.

block.head: Fuel TankDraining

caution.para:
Fuel Tank Drain
ADrain
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

block.para: Turn drain (A) at the bottom of the fuel tank to drain the fuel.

block.head: Fuel PrecleanerShutoff Valve

caution.para:
Fuel Precleaner Shut Off
AValve
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

block.para: Close valve (A) when servicing the fuel precleaner.

note.para:
Fuel Precleaner Filter
Fuel Precleaner Parts
APrecleaner Bowl BO-Ring
Do not clean the fuel precleaner and change the primary and secondary fuel filters at the same time. Doing so makes it difficult to restart the machine. Perform this procedure, then run engine before changing the primary and secondary fuel filters.
Clean the fuel precleaner filter if buildup is visible on the filter screen or if a diagnostic trouble code appears. Reset the code after cleaning the filter.

step.para: Start the engine and run 35 minutes at low idle if the machine had not been previously running.
Shut OFF the engine and close the shutoff valve at the top of the precleaner housing to prevent fluid from draining back within the supply line.
Thoroughly clean the fuel precleaner assembly and the surrounding area.
Remove the precleaner bowl (A).
Clean the filter screen and precleaner bowl. Inspect O-ring (B).
Install the screen and tighten precleaner bowl.
Open the shutoff valve to fill the precleaner.
Start the engine and run 35 minutes at low idle.

Fuel Precleaner Filter (Heavy-Duty)
AFuel Precleaner Filter BDrain Valve
Start the engine and run 35 minutes at low idle if the machine had not been previously operating.
Shut OFF engine and close valve on the fuel precleaner.
Thoroughly clean the exterior of the fuel precleaner filter and the filter mounting area.

note.para: Use a catch pan when draining fuel and when removing fuel precleaner filter.

step.para: Drain the fuel contaminates from the fuel precleaner filter (A) by opening the drain valve (B).
Close the drain valve and remove the fuel precleaner filter.
Install the previously removed separator bowl onto the replacement fuel precleaner filter.

important.para: Do NOT prefill fuel precleaner filter with fuel.

note.para: Lube the filter seal with diesel fuel before installing

step.para: Install the fuel precleaner filter assembly. Tighten the filter assembly with 3/4 of a turn after the seal contacts the filter housing.
Verify that drain valve is closed.
Open valve on the fuel precleaner.
Turn key switch ON for 60 seconds to allow fuel pump to prime the fuel system.
Start engine and run 35 minutes at low idle. If engine does not start or dies, see Primary and Secondary Fuel Filter ElementReplacing.

caution.para:
Water Separator Primary Fuel Filter
APrimary Fuel Filter BDrain
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key before performing maintenance work.

step.para: When primary fuel filter (A) senses water in the fuel system, a diagnostic trouble code is generated.
If a diagnostic trouble code appears, drain the primary filter using drain (B) and reset the code.

block.object_name: Primary and Secondary Fuel Filter Element-Replacing
block.head: Primary and Secondary Fuel Filter ElementReplacing

caution.para:
Primary Filter
APrimary Fuel Filter BFilter Slot (2 used) CHousing Tab (2 used)
High-pressure fluid remaining in fuel lines can cause serious injury. Before disconnecting the fuel lines, sensors, or any other components between the high-pressure fuel pump and nozzles, wait a minimum of 15 minutes after the engine is stopped.
Before performing maintenance work on the fuel filter, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key.

step.para: Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove and replace the primary fuel filter (A).
Disconnect the water sensor (if equipped).
Remove the fuel from the filter and discard.
Lubricate the replacement primary fuel filter seal with a thin film of oil or fuel.
Align the filter slots (B) on the primary fuel filter with housing tabs (C).
Install and tighten the primary fuel filter until it is hand-tight.
Tighten primary fuel filter by an additional 1/2 turn.
Open the valve on the fuel precleaner.
To prime the fuel system, turn the key switch to the ON position for 60 seconds.
Start the engine and run 35 minutes at low idle.

Secondary Fuel Filter
ASecondary Fuel Filter BFilter Slot (2 used) CHousing Tab (2 used)
Close the valve on the fuel precleaner.
Remove and replace the secondary fuel filter (A).

To prime the fuel system, turn the key switch to the ON position for 60 seconds.
Start the engine and run 35 minutes at low idle.

block.head: Fuel SystemBleeding

caution.para:
Fuel Pump

block.para: Air can enter the fuel system when changing the fuel filters or when the machine has run out of fuel. Air in the fuel system could prevent the engine from starting. If the engine does not start, turn the key switch ON for 60 seconds to allow the fuel pump (A) to prime the fuel system.

caution.para:
Radiator Safety
Radiator Drain
ADrain Valve
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key. Avoid being scalded when opening the surge tank cap. Never open the cap when the engine is hot. Open the cap slowly to relieve the pressure.

note.para: Radiator drain is on the rear side of the radiator.
When Cool-GardCool-Gard is a trademark of Deere & Company II or Cool-Gard II PG is used, the drain interval is 6 years or 6000 hours of operation.
If a coolant other than Cool-Gard II or Cool-Gard II PG is used, reduce the drain interval to 2 years or 2000 hours of operation.
Coolant must be drained and replaced. See Fuels and Lubricants section for engine coolant recommendations.

step.para: Open drain valve (A) on the radiator.

Front Side of Engine
ADrain Valve
Open drain valve (A) on the engine block.

Surge Tank
ASurge Tank Cap
Open surge tank cap (A) to allow coolant to drain faster.
Close the radiator drains and fill the system with clean water.
Install the surge tank cap and run the engine until it reaches operating temperature with the heater ON.
Shut OFF the engine, carefully remove the surge tank cap, and drain out the water before rust or sediment settles.
Close the radiator drains and refill the system with a solution of clean water and John Deere Cooling System Cleaner PT500 or equivalent. Follow the instructions with the cleaner.
After using the cleaner, flush the system with clean water and drain.
Close the radiator drains and fill the system. See Cooling SystemFilling in this section for filling procedure. See Fuels and Lubricants section for engine coolant recommendations.

caution.para:
Surge Tank
ASurge Tank Cap BMax Cold Line
Shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key. Avoid being scalded when opening the surge tank cap. Never open the cap when the engine is hot and never fill cooling system when the engine is overheated. Open the cap slowly to relieve pressure. Pour the coolant in slowly. Check the coolant level when engine is cold.

important.para: A special cap is used on the surge tank and radiator. If the cap is damaged or missing, it must be replaced by an equivalent cap.
Never pour cold water into a hot engine, as it might crack the cylinder block or head. Do not operate the engine without coolant.

step.para: Remove surge tank cap (A) and fill until fluid is at the "Max Cold" line (B).
Install the cap on the surge tank, turn ON the heater, and run the engine until it reaches operating temperature.
Carefully remove the cap from the surge tank and refill as necessary. Install the cap on the surge tank.
When the engine is cool, the coolant level should be at the "Max Cold" line.

note.para: Coolant level must be between the "Max Cold" and "Min Cold" lines. Add coolant as needed if the coolant is below the "Min Cold" line.

block.head: Cooling SystemWinterize

important.para: Do not drain cooling system to protect against freezing. Heater does not drain completely, so damage would result.

block.para: Before cold weather, be sure that cooling system has enough antifreeze. Use a reliable brand of permanent-type ethylene glycol antifreeze which contains a rust inhibitor and water pump lubricant, but does not contain a leak-stopping additive. See Fuels and Lubricants in this manual for correct recommendations.
After adding antifreeze, turn heater ON and run engine until it reaches operating temperature. This mixes the solution and circulates it through the system.

important.para:
Air Filter Dust Cover
Air Filters
ADust Cover BPrimary Air Filter CSafety Filter
When servicing the filters, shut OFF engine, set park brake, and remove key so dirt cannot be pulled into the engine.
Service the filters only when the engine air filter icon is displayed on the armrest display.

step.para: Unsnap dust cover (A) and remove the primary air filter (B).
Unscrew safety filter (C) in a counterclockwise direction to remove. The safety filter stops dirt that would pass through a damaged primary filter.

important.para: Never wash, brush, or knock the elements. If blowing out the primary element, use dry compressed air no greater than 500 kPa (5 bar) (72.5 psi). Clean the element from the inside out, making sure that the tip of the air gun does not come in contact with the filter paper.
Never clean the safety element. Replace if dirty.
Never run the engine without both filters in place.

step.para: Service the filters as needed.
Install the safety filter and turn in a clockwise direction until hand-tight.
Install the primary air filter and dust cover.
Check all connections in the air intake system. Be certain that they are tight.

important.para: Do not use any exhaust flow cleaning unit to blow chaff off the combine. Using such a unit can cause air filter failure, followed by engine failure.

Never clean the engine air filters while the engine is running.

note.para: For optimal air compressor performance, the engine must be running to provide continuous air supply.
It is not recommended to inflate the tires on the machine or operate air tools.
It is not recommended to use both of the coupler connections simultaneously.

block.para: The air compressor is on the engine, and the reservoir (A) is on the right-hand side of the machine.
The air compressor hose couplers are located:

item.para: (B) Under the right-hand landing.
(C) On the tailings elevator.
(D) On the hydraulic reservoir.

block.para: The air compressor hose/wand (E) is on the tailings elevator.

block.object_name: Diesel Particulate Filter Aftertreatment Replacement (Stage V)
block.head: Diesel Particulate Filter Aftertreatment Replacement (Stage V)
block.para: Diesel Particulate Filter The exhaust filter includes the diesel oxidation catalyst and diesel particulate filter (DPF). The DPF is designed to retain residual ash, which is a noncombustible result of additives used in crankcase lubrication oils and the fuel. The DPF provides many hours of maintenance-free operation. At some point, the DPF requires professional service or replacement to remove the accumulated ash. The exact number of hours of operation before service or replacement is required varies depending upon the engines power category, duty cycle and operating conditions, engine oil ash content, and fuel quality. Adhering to John Deeres recommended oil and fuel specifications will maximize the hours of operation before professional DPF service or replacement is required.

As the engine owner, you are responsible for performing the required maintenance described in your Operators Manual. During normal equipment operation, the DPF maintenance requirements will depend on the rate at which ash accumulates in it. DPFs on engines above 175 hp/130 kW may require service or replacement at about 4500 hours. As ash levels rise in the DPF, the capacity for soot storage is reduced and the back pressure of the exhaust system will rise more frequently. A diagnostic trouble code will appear, indicating when the DPF needs servicing.

The removal of DPF ash must be done by removing the DPF from the machine and placing it into specialized equipment. Do not remove ash by using water or chemicals. Removing ash by these methods may damage the material securing the DPF in its canister, resulting in the loosening of the DPF element in the canister and subjecting it to damage from vibration.

Failure to follow the approved ash removal methods may violate U.S. federal, state, and local hazardous waste laws, and may also damage the DPF, resulting in potential denial of the diesel exhaust filter emissions warranty. It is strongly recommended you take the DPF to an authorized John Deere service location or other qualified service provider for service or replacement.
When AUTO or PARKED cleaning is enabled, the exhaust temperature may be high under no load or light load conditions at certain times during the exhaust filter cleaning cycle.
Disable exhaust filter cleaning system in conditions where it may be unsafe for elevated exhaust temperatures.
Disable the automatic exhaust filter cleaning system only when necessary.

block.object_name: Exhaust Filter - Diesel Particulate Filter Ash Handling and Disposal (Stage V)
block.head: Exhaust Filter / Diesel Particulate Filter Ash Handling and Disposal (Stage V)

caution.para: Under federal, state, and/or local laws or regulations, diesel particulate filter (DPF) ash may be classified as a hazardous waste. Hazardous waste must be disposed of in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local laws or regulations governing hazardous waste disposal. Only a qualified service provider should remove ash from the DPF. Personal protective equipment and clothing, maintained in a sanitary and reliable condition, should be used when handling and cleaning a DPF. See your John Deere dealer or qualified service provider for assistance.

Proper management of an exhaust filter that has reached the end of its useful life is required, since the ash or catalyst material in the device may be classified as hazardous waste under federal, state, and/or local laws or regulations. Used exhaust filter, which includes the diesel particulate filter (DPF), may be exchanged at any John Deere dealer or qualified service provider.

block.head: Preparing Machine for Storage
block.para: Swing out condenser and oil cooler and clean radiator with air, water, or a vacuum cleaner.
Clean condenser and oil cooler after cleaning radiator. Clean charge air cooler.

Every 6090 days, start engine and turn air conditioning ON. Run engine at low idle for several minutes for compressor seal lubrication. Outside temperature should be above 5C (40F) for proper air conditioning operation.
Clean the surfaces of the engine with a safe solvent.

caution.para: Do not use gasoline for cleaning.

block.para: Clean inside the air cleaner and install new elements.
Drain the engine crankcase while the engine is warm. Replace filter and fill with correct oil. Add 0.66 L (22 oz) of a corrosion inhibitor to the engine crankcase. Run engine to circulate.
Drain, flush, and refill cooling system with 50/50 mixture of antifreeze and water.

important.para: Long-term storage in vehicle (over 12 months) is not recommended. If long-term storage is necessary, periodic testing of diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) is recommended to ensure that urea concentration does not fall out of specification.

block.para: Final Tier 4/Stage V: Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) has a limited shelf life, but it may be stored in the vehicle for as long as 12 months, depending upon storage conditions. See Storing Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) and Refilling Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Tank in Fuels and Lubricants section for further information. See Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) TankFilling and Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) TankDraining in MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information.

important.para: Final Tier 4/Stage V: Do not disconnect battery for at least 90 seconds after machine is shut OFF. Selective catalyst reduction (SCR) system automatically purges lines of diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) during this time, immediately after machine is shut OFF. If adequate time is not allowed for lines to be purged, any fluid remaining in lines can crystallize and plug lines. Fluid freezes and possibly burst lines in freezing weather conditions.

note.para: Turn battery disconnect switch OFF if machine is stored longer than 25 days. If storage period is longer than 90 days, remove negative lead to batteries to minimize load to batteries.

block.para: Charge batteries completely. Specific gravity equals 1.260 volts. To minimize load to the batteries, remove the negative lead to the batteries.
Drain water separator.
Clean machine inside and out. Leave elevator doors and drain covers open.
Cycle concave up and down several times to prevent material buildup in the concave area.

important.para: Directing pressurized water at electronic/electrical components or connectors, bearings and hydraulic seals, fuel injection pumps, or other sensitive parts and components may cause product malfunctions. Reduce pressure, and spray at a 45 to 90 angle.

block.para: Repaint areas where needed.

note.para: It is not necessary to wax the machine. However, if desired, use a good clear wax that contains no abrasives. These types of waxes usually do not contain cleaners.

block.para: Lubricate machine and grease adjusting bolt threads.
Perform all 400 hours (yearly) services.
To prevent condensation, fill fuel tank.

important.para: To stabilize the fuel and prevent water condensation, add fuel conditioner when the following occurs:

item.para: Fuel is stored in the fuel tanks (machine or farm storage) for extended periods of time. See your John Deere dealer for recommendations.
A slow turnover of fuel is being used. See your John Deere dealer for recommendations.

important.para: For prolonged machine storage, the best practice is to drain biodiesel and fill machine with regular petroleum diesel fuel. Otherwise, use biodiesel stabilizer (anti-oxidant) additives or fully formulated biodiesel conditioners. See your John Deere dealer for recommendations.

block.para: If machine is to be stored for a long period, remove and clean the batteries. Store them in a cool, dry place and keep them fully charged.
Before storing the machine, the air compressor reservoir (if equipped) MUST be drained of water.
It is recommended to lower the feeder house roughly 50 mm (2 in) before shutting the machine off for long term storage or service.

block.head: Removing Machine from Storage
block.para: Reconnect and/or charge batteries.
Charge batteries completely. Specific gravity equals 1.260 volts. To minimize load to the batteries, remove negative lead to the batteries.
Check oil and coolant levels. Inspect for leaks and add oil and coolant if needed.

Final Tier 4/Stage V: If diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) tank was not drained, test urea concentration. See Testing Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) in Fuels and Lubricants section for further information. If concentration is not within specifications, drain and replace with new diesel exhaust fluid (DEF). If diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) tank was drained, fill tank. See Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) TankFilling in MaintenanceAs Required (Engine Fluids and Filters) section for further information.

Replace the ActiveVisionActiveVision is a trademark of Deere & Company clean grain elevator camera and tailings system camera desiccant cartridge (if equipped). See ActiveVision Camera Desiccant Cartridge in MaintenanceEvery 400 Hours section for further information.
Close elevator doors and drain hole.
Check tension of drive belts. Adjust spring-loaded idlers until the washer is positioned between the end of the gauge and the bottom of the step.
Check tire inflation and review machine Operator's Manual.
Inspect fire extinguishers (front and left-hand side) by following maintenance instructions on the fire extinguisher label. Recharge or replace as necessary.
